game_genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Free To Play
review_text:
Been playing this game for years now, so here are my 2 cents on the game for new players.

This game is hard, like vary hard, if you are new you will die a lot to older players.  So here are a few things you can do to get better at the game.

1. Don't cheat.  You will not get better if you do cheat and you will make the game worse by doing so.
2. Listen to your surroundings.  This can make you win or loss a game just because you could not hear where the other players shots are coming from so you put your back towards the player shooting at you instead of facing them.
3. Do not land at popular sites, this is an easy and fast way to go back to the lobby, instead look for locations at least 1km from where the plane is flying and go there.
4. Play with friends and use VOIP.  You can use the in game VOIP, but what I use is Discord.
5. Don't go more then 100 m from your team mates.  This way when one of you is in trouble, 3 of your team mates are at positions to aid you.  Also don't be to close to each other, as this makes you easier to spot and makes it harder for you and your team mates to return fire when you are in a fire fight.
6. When you see someone, ping them so your team mates know where they are and can aid it taking them down.
7. Take a automatic weapon and a long range weapon (DMR or SR).  My suggestion for a new player is a SMG and a DMR.  For SMG use one of the 3, UMP, VECTOR, MP5K.  As for DMR's, use SLR or DRAGUNOV.
8. Carry at least 4 First Aid kits, 10 bandages, and 4 boosts.
9. Carry 2-3 Smoke grenades.
10. Just have fun.

review_text: The player who uses the perspective cheating function cheats by reporting the location to his teammates. When the player is killed, he can only report the cheating teammate but not the cheater. He can only enter the spectator mode after the whole team dies. However, the cheating team often leaves one member of our team unkilled, making it impossible for the player to spectate the cheating team and accurately find the perspective cheater.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!

I didn’t expect to like this game. As an old-school Diablo 2 fan, I was skeptical, but with all the hype and seeing it on sale, I decided to give it a try. Somehow, the game sucks you in. It’s like watching grandma at the casino—every slot machine is hitting. Some of the payouts are pennies, and some are much bigger, but the idea that you might hit big or miss out on the next great item or event keeps you hooked.

There’s a lot of flash and bang, action-packed gore to keep things interesting, and plenty of ways to build your character. You can easily spend hours just sitting at your stash, or googling new ways to improve a single build. I wouldn’t say it’s the best game out there, but it definitely does the job when it comes to keeping you entertained.

I held off on buying this game for a long time because I do not want to support the idea of a battle pass.  I find they often ruin great games.  I eventually gave in and bought this during a trial period and really enjoyed it, so much so that I bought it, despite my grumblings against it.  Since then I've enjoyed it, despite the battle pass, which only has cosmetic rewards.  I still don't love the idea of a battle pass but the fact that the battle pass is purely cosmetic helps water it down for me.  Another thing that helps greatly is that the free tier of armor looks really amazing.  They didn't skimp on armor cosmetics to try and guide people towards buying cosmetics, which is a big plus and actually the only reason I would recommend the game.  As far as game play goes, it's been really fun.  End game is a little complicated and to get anywhere you have to follow someone else's build but that's pretty standard for RPGs these days.

Each time I loaded up the game I couldn't keep playing for more than an hour because I nodded off! Even D3 was more fun!

Look, I'm being harsh, but I played 76 hours hoping that maybe the endgame will change how I feel about this game, but it's no more exciting than playing catch with a toddler.

Perfect for the steam deck as long as you have an internet connection. Easy time killer, fun to play and easy to learn. This is my first time playing with this IP and I am having a blast. Starting multiple characters and seeing how they change your playstyle is more fun than I thought it would be and lots of game left even after you've finished the campaign. I would recommend it for someone who likes a strategy game mixed with slaying monsters and creatures from a high 3rd person view style. The visuals are also quite good especially on the steam deck; which is what I buy a lot of games for since I travel a ton. Expansion coming in October as well to continue the story and add new game mechanics, characters and abilities. The only downside I have with this game is that it needs to be connected to the internet the entire time and you can not play offline.

Monkey King's Reign: The Global Impact of 'Black Myth: Wukong'
By KAI WOOD|Aug 26,2024
Chongqing - Black Myth: Wukong, a Chinese AAA game, has taken the gaming world by storm, smashing sales records and captivating millions of players with its breathtaking combat, stellar production quality, and unforgettable boss fights. Despite some skepticism from Western media outlets like IGN, the game has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from gamers around the globe. To explore what makes this game so special, Bridging News reached out to some Western gamers in China.

The New Evolution of Action RPG: 'Black Myth: Wukong'
Jacob Kapustinski, a dedicated gamer from Connecticut who is now living in Chongqing, China,  shared his thoughts on what makes this game stand out. 

Jacob's gaming journey began almost as soon as he could hold a controller. "I've been gaming my entire life," he recalls. "I was sitting on my dad’s lap, controller in hand, by the time I was three." His move to China seven years ago broadened his gaming interests. "Moving here, I've started appreciating different gaming styles, especially Chinese RPGs like Black Myth: Wukong." Jacob’s enthusiasm for the game is evident. "When the first trailer dropped five years ago, I was hooked. It was clear this game would be something special, and it hasn’t disappointed."


A Game That Lives Up to the Hype


Incredible cover art for the new AAA Game Black Myth: Wukong (Photo by Game Science)


"This game lives up to every bit of its hype," Jacob states. "It’s visually stunning, with tight controls and an engaging story. It's definitely China’s big entry into the AAA market." With about 30 hours of gameplay, Jacob is convinced of its impact. "It’s the new evolution of action RPGs, blending the best elements of Souls-like games with unique Chinese mythology. It’s a game that both challenges and immerses."

To get a sense of the local reaction, Huang HuiJing, a young man in Chongqing, thought of it as a hardcore Chinese gamer. "Every character has his own story, and it's a deeply Chinese story that is very meaningful to Chinese people. It's amazing. My friends and I, we all love it very much," he said before quickly returning to finish his boss fight. 

Showcasing Chongqing on a Global Stage


The UNESCO World Heritage Site Dazu Buddhist Sculptures are brought to the incredible and stunning fantasy world in Black Myth: WuKong (Photo by Game Science)


What sets Black Myth: Wukong apart is its deep cultural roots. Set against the backdrop of iconic Chinese locations like Chongqing’s Baoding Mountains and the Dazu Buddhist sculptures, the game weaves real-world beauty into its fantasy. "It’s fantasy, sure, but it’s so deeply rooted in real places that it makes you appreciate China’s culture and landscapes," Jacob explains. "This game is like a love letter to China. It’s going to make people around the world curious about these places, about Chongqing."

Igniting Conversations and Curiosity
Beyond its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Black Myth: Wukong is sparking deeper cultural conversations. James Mitchell, a Scottish teacher who lived in Chongqing before moving to the sunny beaches of Sanya, has noticed a shift in how people engage with Chinese mythology. "The game has spurred a lot of conversations about Chinese mythology," he observes. "My wife, who usually isn’t interested in gaming, is now fully engaged. She explains the mythical creatures and the rich lore behind them. It’s fascinating to see how the game brings these ancient stories to life, resonating with both Chinese and international audiences."

For James, Black Myth: Wukong's impact extends far beyond entertainment. "It’s a modern platform that not only entertains but also educates," he says. The game acts as an eye-opener for many players, offering a glimpse into history and mythology that they might not have explored otherwise."

James is eager to bring these discussions into his classroom. "I’m looking forward to encouraging students to explore and express their opinions on the game," he adds, "and to delve into the rich cultural heritage it portrays." This educational potential highlights Black Myth: Wukong's unique role in bridging cultural gaps and promoting a deeper understanding of Chinese mythology.

Facing Criticism Head-On


Asmongold, a top YouTube influencer known for his reactions and comments on new games, has heartily endorsed Black Myth: Wukong (Photo from Asmongold)


Despite its success, Black Myth: Wukong hasn’t escaped criticism, particularly from Western media. Jacob shrugs off the negativity. "Critics will always find something to nitpick, but the players love it. That’s what counts." YouTube personality Asmongold chimed in on the controversy, suggesting that the criticisms from outlets like IGN might stem from commercial motives rather than genuine concern. "They're more concerned with staying relevant than with what gamers actually want," Asmongold argues. "And gamers want Wukong."

A New Era for Chinese Gaming


Black Myth: Wukong, China's first AAA action-adventure game, has broken all records for single-player games already and shows no signs of slowing down (Photo from Game Science)

Jacob is excited about what Black Myth: Wukong means for the future. "China's mostly been known for mobile games, but this changes everything. Now, the world knows that China can produce big, high-quality, culturally rich games. This is just the beginning," he emphasizes. "This game shows that China is in the big leagues now, and it's only going to get better. We’re going to see more great games, a lot more like this, more China-made and Chinese culture games."

Black Myth: Wukong is more than a game; it's a cultural phenomenon, bridging gaps between East and West. As Jacob enthusiastically notes, "This isn't just about gaming—it's about sharing our stories, our culture, and showing the world what we can do."


Jorah Kai, the author of Kai's Diary, Amos the Amazing, and the soon-to-be-released A Sun Also Rises on Cthulhu, is both a big fan of action games and Chinese culture. Here, he stands on the Great Wall of China, protecting it against monsters and those who would blemish Sun Wukong's great legacy. (Photo by Jorah Kai)

Forced to make psn account. Then it made me log in manually instead of auto-logging me in after making it (it's 2024 Sony come on). Already annoyed but it's fine, once and done I thought. NOPE.

It asked me to verify my account from email omg... but yay I saw a "do this later" option which I clicked on. This basically ended the game. Wow. Why are you offering this if it's a lie?

Reloaded game. Opened internet browser and verified stupid email for Sony. Tabbed over to the game and it wouldn't open. After maybe 20 seconds it crashed and Steam gave me a pop up error crash message. So sony PSN account nonsense crashed my game.

Reloaded game. Quite irritated at this point. I had to manually log in again to PSN. It asked me to verify account but I was able to click on "already verified" to get past that. FINALLY I thought... NOPE.

It asked me some annoying questions and terms and data crap but I saw a "do this later" button which I clicked on once again because this shouldn't matter I thought, I should be able to do this later in Settings or something. This ended the game again................................

I reloaded the game and guess what, had to manually log in AGAIN. So damn mad at this point.

I ignored the stupid "do this later" button which should've never existed in the first place because you literally cannot play if you click on it.

Finally got to the damn start screen. I went into settings and maxed everything out as usual. 4090/7950x3d/64gb. Game crashed in settings. I confirmed amd and nvidia drivers were up to date, which they were. Reloaded game.

Finally after like a half hour of bullshit I'm able to play. Thanks Sony! Negative review until the end of time from me.

In the future, any game requiring a PSN account from me will get a negative review even if the game blows my mind.

God of war Ragnarok is a rare type of sequel in the sense that its better than the first game in almost every way. The combat is much more refined to deliver a similar yet more polished experience than the 2018 game. The story itself is a very gripping and enthralling ride that I havent even finished yet despite me having almost 30 hours on the game and im just barely entering the final act. The side missions are very interesting and give some good lore about the areas you explore some of them even relating to characters Kratos and Atreus have encountered before, some of the rewards feel a bit lackluster at times but the game is typically pretty fair with the loot you get. Speaking of side content, there are a plethera of hidden bosses that i've encountered that if succeeding against them can easily get you a lot of xp and hacksilver, the boss fights are challenging yet fun that also feature a lot of different mechanics. Exploring more of the 9 realms is a journey in itself with each realm having a vibrant and unique look and feel, the graphics on this game are very good and sony delivered a very solid PC port so props to them. All in all id give this game a solid 9.5/10 so far, the only critique i could even have for it is that i wish the game was longer however, they were kind enough to make the free Valhalla DLC which is a roguelike experience in the post game that you can get a lot of time out of in itself.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.
One of the Best Story DLCs I've seen in recent years. Loved the story and sat a solid 10 minutes at the end pondering what decisions to make.

An extremely well polished thriller. I was absolutely hooked! As I mentioned in my review of the base game, the decisions you make in the base game and DLC, and their consequences stay in your mind even long after you're done playing the game.

The game is in a very good state now than it was at launch, and I highly recommend playing it now if you didn't back when it launched.

Very demure

Cyberpunk isn't a good game by any measure and the less of its setting leaks into the real world, the better but if you do end up playing it, get Phantom Liberty and ignore the main game to the best of your ability.
The dlc is its own thing pretty much with an extra ending of its own, which has the added benefit of skipping the remainder of the core vidya.

Now, onto the good things: the script, the pacing, the dialogues, the execution of a properly polished thriller. The DLC adds some extra missions for old fixers. Fetch quests aside, the quest are good too, adding depth and nuance to the NPCs. Though the most important is the selection of end-game choices you're presented with. Between wetwork, dubious loyalties and complex motivations of dramatis personaes, someone did their homework on intelligence services so a lot of it offers a very authentic experience. A lot of times you leave feeling dirty - because that is the nature of the work. My only criticism is you couldn't off Meyers (it'd be tons of fun, I think), but otherwise it's next to excellent. Johnny's dialogue at the end of the lunar escape was a rare gem, diverging from his usual abrasive rants. Meeting Mr Hands in person was somewhat of a letdown, but more gigs from the sphinxian villain was welcome.

It's difficult to believe the DLC was produced by the same studio as the cliché and filth-filled dumpster fire that is the core game. The setting remains as disgusting as ever, with humanity locked in a dull and primitive state of neo-feudal corporate overlords or communes of plain-roaming barbarians, but Phantom Liberty redeems the price tag. If you find a way to skip to the DLC and just play the extra, do it: it is a real treat for any lovers of a spy drama - something Deux Ex tried and failed to do.

Edit: ending credits animation film was an outstanding tribute to the classic James Bond movies. Stellar.

PREEM DLC
It's the best expansion for a single player game ever made, and its not even close. Blood & Wine was amazing, but Phantom Liberty is stunning.
AMAZING

Ah, “Phantom Liberty,” where the neon lights are brighter, the stakes are higher, and the glitches are… well, let’s just say they’re part of the charm. Imagine if James Bond, Keanu Reeves, and Idris Elba decided to throw a party in Night City, and you get to clean up the mess. That’s Phantom Liberty for you.

The expansion kicks off with the President of the New United States crash-landing in Dogtown. Yes, you read that right. Apparently, Air Force One now comes with a “crash here for plot development” button. You’re hired to rescue her, but not before you navigate through a maze of cybernetic baddies, morally ambiguous choices, and enough plot twists to make a pretzel jealous.

Idris Elba’s character, Solomon Reed, is the secret agent we all wish we could be. He’s suave, he’s mysterious, and he probably has a better skincare routine than you. Meanwhile, Keanu Reeves returns as Johnny Silverhand, still rocking that “I hate the system” vibe but with a touch more existential dread. It’s like watching your cool uncle go through a mid-life crisis, but with more explosions.

Dogtown itself is a marvel. It’s like someone took all the worst parts of a dystopian future and decided to make it a tourist attraction. The local wildlife includes cyber-enhanced gangsters and vending machines that might just try to sell you a grenade. But hey, at least the street food is to die for—literally.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment you’re making life-or-death decisions, the next you’re wondering why your character’s pants have suddenly disappeared. It’s all part of the Cyberpunk experience, folks. Embrace the chaos.

In conclusion, Phantom Liberty is the perfect blend of high-stakes drama, cybernetic mayhem, and unintentional comedy. It’s like a soap opera set in a dystopian future, and honestly, we wouldn’t have it any other way. So, grab your cyberdeck, put on your best trench coat, and dive into the madness. Just watch out for those vending machines.

review_text:
Been playing this game for years now, so here are my 2 cents on the game for new players.

This game is hard, like vary hard, if you are new you will die a lot to older players.  So here are a few things you can do to get better at the game.

1. Don't cheat.  You will not get better if you do cheat and you will make the game worse by doing so.
2. Listen to your surroundings.  This can make you win or loss a game just because you could not hear where the other players shots are coming from so you put your back towards the player shooting at you instead of facing them.
3. Do not land at popular sites, this is an easy and fast way to go back to the lobby, instead look for locations at least 1km from where the plane is flying and go there.
4. Play with friends and use VOIP.  You can use the in game VOIP, but what I use is Discord.
5. Don't go more then 100 m from your team mates.  This way when one of you is in trouble, 3 of your team mates are at positions to aid you.  Also don't be to close to each other, as this makes you easier to spot and makes it harder for you and your team mates to return fire when you are in a fire fight.
6. When you see someone, ping them so your team mates know where they are and can aid it taking them down.
7. Take a automatic weapon and a long range weapon (DMR or SR).  My suggestion for a new player is a SMG and a DMR.  For SMG use one of the 3, UMP, VECTOR, MP5K.  As for DMR's, use SLR or DRAGUNOV.
8. Carry at least 4 First Aid kits, 10 bandages, and 4 boosts.
9. Carry 2-3 Smoke grenades.
10. Just have fun.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!

I didn’t expect to like this game. As an old-school Diablo 2 fan, I was skeptical, but with all the hype and seeing it on sale, I decided to give it a try. Somehow, the game sucks you in. It’s like watching grandma at the casino—every slot machine is hitting. Some of the payouts are pennies, and some are much bigger, but the idea that you might hit big or miss out on the next great item or event keeps you hooked.

There’s a lot of flash and bang, action-packed gore to keep things interesting, and plenty of ways to build your character. You can easily spend hours just sitting at your stash, or googling new ways to improve a single build. I wouldn’t say it’s the best game out there, but it definitely does the job when it comes to keeping you entertained.

combat system, items , level up systems and campaign for first 30 - 40 hours is fun after that anything else is boring and you have to farming dungeons and bosses for some items you need in order to upgrade your armors or swords AND after that you recognize you don't need those upgrades because world bosses and legion bosses are a lot weaker than you specially when you want to play with your friends you don't need to do anything because most of bosses are a lot weaker than you.
if you want to have fun for 30 - 40 hours or you like some farming games buying season pass and these stuffs it's a good game, But if you looking for more than, it's not ideal game.

I held off on buying this game for a long time because I do not want to support the idea of a battle pass.  I find they often ruin great games.  I eventually gave in and bought this during a trial period and really enjoyed it, so much so that I bought it, despite my grumblings against it.  Since then I've enjoyed it, despite the battle pass, which only has cosmetic rewards.  I still don't love the idea of a battle pass but the fact that the battle pass is purely cosmetic helps water it down for me.  Another thing that helps greatly is that the free tier of armor looks really amazing.  They didn't skimp on armor cosmetics to try and guide people towards buying cosmetics, which is a big plus and actually the only reason I would recommend the game.  As far as game play goes, it's been really fun.  End game is a little complicated and to get anywhere you have to follow someone else's build but that's pretty standard for RPGs these days.

Perfect for the steam deck as long as you have an internet connection. Easy time killer, fun to play and easy to learn. This is my first time playing with this IP and I am having a blast. Starting multiple characters and seeing how they change your playstyle is more fun than I thought it would be and lots of game left even after you've finished the campaign. I would recommend it for someone who likes a strategy game mixed with slaying monsters and creatures from a high 3rd person view style. The visuals are also quite good especially on the steam deck; which is what I buy a lot of games for since I travel a ton. Expansion coming in October as well to continue the story and add new game mechanics, characters and abilities. The only downside I have with this game is that it needs to be connected to the internet the entire time and you can not play offline.

Monkey King's Reign: The Global Impact of 'Black Myth: Wukong'
By KAI WOOD|Aug 26,2024
Chongqing - Black Myth: Wukong, a Chinese AAA game, has taken the gaming world by storm, smashing sales records and captivating millions of players with its breathtaking combat, stellar production quality, and unforgettable boss fights. Despite some skepticism from Western media outlets like IGN, the game has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from gamers around the globe. To explore what makes this game so special, Bridging News reached out to some Western gamers in China.

The New Evolution of Action RPG: 'Black Myth: Wukong'
Jacob Kapustinski, a dedicated gamer from Connecticut who is now living in Chongqing, China,  shared his thoughts on what makes this game stand out. 

Jacob's gaming journey began almost as soon as he could hold a controller. "I've been gaming my entire life," he recalls. "I was sitting on my dad’s lap, controller in hand, by the time I was three." His move to China seven years ago broadened his gaming interests. "Moving here, I've started appreciating different gaming styles, especially Chinese RPGs like Black Myth: Wukong." Jacob’s enthusiasm for the game is evident. "When the first trailer dropped five years ago, I was hooked. It was clear this game would be something special, and it hasn’t disappointed."


A Game That Lives Up to the Hype


Incredible cover art for the new AAA Game Black Myth: Wukong (Photo by Game Science)


"This game lives up to every bit of its hype," Jacob states. "It’s visually stunning, with tight controls and an engaging story. It's definitely China’s big entry into the AAA market." With about 30 hours of gameplay, Jacob is convinced of its impact. "It’s the new evolution of action RPGs, blending the best elements of Souls-like games with unique Chinese mythology. It’s a game that both challenges and immerses."

To get a sense of the local reaction, Huang HuiJing, a young man in Chongqing, thought of it as a hardcore Chinese gamer. "Every character has his own story, and it's a deeply Chinese story that is very meaningful to Chinese people. It's amazing. My friends and I, we all love it very much," he said before quickly returning to finish his boss fight. 

Showcasing Chongqing on a Global Stage


The UNESCO World Heritage Site Dazu Buddhist Sculptures are brought to the incredible and stunning fantasy world in Black Myth: WuKong (Photo by Game Science)


What sets Black Myth: Wukong apart is its deep cultural roots. Set against the backdrop of iconic Chinese locations like Chongqing’s Baoding Mountains and the Dazu Buddhist sculptures, the game weaves real-world beauty into its fantasy. "It’s fantasy, sure, but it’s so deeply rooted in real places that it makes you appreciate China’s culture and landscapes," Jacob explains. "This game is like a love letter to China. It’s going to make people around the world curious about these places, about Chongqing."

Igniting Conversations and Curiosity
Beyond its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Black Myth: Wukong is sparking deeper cultural conversations. James Mitchell, a Scottish teacher who lived in Chongqing before moving to the sunny beaches of Sanya, has noticed a shift in how people engage with Chinese mythology. "The game has spurred a lot of conversations about Chinese mythology," he observes. "My wife, who usually isn’t interested in gaming, is now fully engaged. She explains the mythical creatures and the rich lore behind them. It’s fascinating to see how the game brings these ancient stories to life, resonating with both Chinese and international audiences."

For James, Black Myth: Wukong's impact extends far beyond entertainment. "It’s a modern platform that not only entertains but also educates," he says. The game acts as an eye-opener for many players, offering a glimpse into history and mythology that they might not have explored otherwise."

James is eager to bring these discussions into his classroom. "I’m looking forward to encouraging students to explore and express their opinions on the game," he adds, "and to delve into the rich cultural heritage it portrays." This educational potential highlights Black Myth: Wukong's unique role in bridging cultural gaps and promoting a deeper understanding of Chinese mythology.

Facing Criticism Head-On


Asmongold, a top YouTube influencer known for his reactions and comments on new games, has heartily endorsed Black Myth: Wukong (Photo from Asmongold)


Despite its success, Black Myth: Wukong hasn’t escaped criticism, particularly from Western media. Jacob shrugs off the negativity. "Critics will always find something to nitpick, but the players love it. That’s what counts." YouTube personality Asmongold chimed in on the controversy, suggesting that the criticisms from outlets like IGN might stem from commercial motives rather than genuine concern. "They're more concerned with staying relevant than with what gamers actually want," Asmongold argues. "And gamers want Wukong."

A New Era for Chinese Gaming


Black Myth: Wukong, China's first AAA action-adventure game, has broken all records for single-player games already and shows no signs of slowing down (Photo from Game Science)

Jacob is excited about what Black Myth: Wukong means for the future. "China's mostly been known for mobile games, but this changes everything. Now, the world knows that China can produce big, high-quality, culturally rich games. This is just the beginning," he emphasizes. "This game shows that China is in the big leagues now, and it's only going to get better. We’re going to see more great games, a lot more like this, more China-made and Chinese culture games."

Black Myth: Wukong is more than a game; it's a cultural phenomenon, bridging gaps between East and West. As Jacob enthusiastically notes, "This isn't just about gaming—it's about sharing our stories, our culture, and showing the world what we can do."


Jorah Kai, the author of Kai's Diary, Amos the Amazing, and the soon-to-be-released A Sun Also Rises on Cthulhu, is both a big fan of action games and Chinese culture. Here, he stands on the Great Wall of China, protecting it against monsters and those who would blemish Sun Wukong's great legacy. (Photo by Jorah Kai)

Go put all this vitriol into something else that actually matters to the world and buy this game. Absolutely recommend at full price.

Forced to make psn account. Then it made me log in manually instead of auto-logging me in after making it (it's 2024 Sony come on). Already annoyed but it's fine, once and done I thought. NOPE.

It asked me to verify my account from email omg... but yay I saw a "do this later" option which I clicked on. This basically ended the game. Wow. Why are you offering this if it's a lie?

Reloaded game. Opened internet browser and verified stupid email for Sony. Tabbed over to the game and it wouldn't open. After maybe 20 seconds it crashed and Steam gave me a pop up error crash message. So sony PSN account nonsense crashed my game.

Reloaded game. Quite irritated at this point. I had to manually log in again to PSN. It asked me to verify account but I was able to click on "already verified" to get past that. FINALLY I thought... NOPE.

It asked me some annoying questions and terms and data crap but I saw a "do this later" button which I clicked on once again because this shouldn't matter I thought, I should be able to do this later in Settings or something. This ended the game again................................

I reloaded the game and guess what, had to manually log in AGAIN. So damn mad at this point.

I ignored the stupid "do this later" button which should've never existed in the first place because you literally cannot play if you click on it.

Finally got to the damn start screen. I went into settings and maxed everything out as usual. 4090/7950x3d/64gb. Game crashed in settings. I confirmed amd and nvidia drivers were up to date, which they were. Reloaded game.

Finally after like a half hour of bullshit I'm able to play. Thanks Sony! Negative review until the end of time from me.

In the future, any game requiring a PSN account from me will get a negative review even if the game blows my mind.

God of war Ragnarok is a rare type of sequel in the sense that its better than the first game in almost every way. The combat is much more refined to deliver a similar yet more polished experience than the 2018 game. The story itself is a very gripping and enthralling ride that I havent even finished yet despite me having almost 30 hours on the game and im just barely entering the final act. The side missions are very interesting and give some good lore about the areas you explore some of them even relating to characters Kratos and Atreus have encountered before, some of the rewards feel a bit lackluster at times but the game is typically pretty fair with the loot you get. Speaking of side content, there are a plethera of hidden bosses that i've encountered that if succeeding against them can easily get you a lot of xp and hacksilver, the boss fights are challenging yet fun that also feature a lot of different mechanics. Exploring more of the 9 realms is a journey in itself with each realm having a vibrant and unique look and feel, the graphics on this game are very good and sony delivered a very solid PC port so props to them. All in all id give this game a solid 9.5/10 so far, the only critique i could even have for it is that i wish the game was longer however, they were kind enough to make the free Valhalla DLC which is a roguelike experience in the post game that you can get a lot of time out of in itself.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

Cyberpunk isn't a good game by any measure and the less of its setting leaks into the real world, the better but if you do end up playing it, get Phantom Liberty and ignore the main game to the best of your ability.
The dlc is its own thing pretty much with an extra ending of its own, which has the added benefit of skipping the remainder of the core vidya.

Now, onto the good things: the script, the pacing, the dialogues, the execution of a properly polished thriller. The DLC adds some extra missions for old fixers. Fetch quests aside, the quest are good too, adding depth and nuance to the NPCs. Though the most important is the selection of end-game choices you're presented with. Between wetwork, dubious loyalties and complex motivations of dramatis personaes, someone did their homework on intelligence services so a lot of it offers a very authentic experience. A lot of times you leave feeling dirty - because that is the nature of the work. My only criticism is you couldn't off Meyers (it'd be tons of fun, I think), but otherwise it's next to excellent. Johnny's dialogue at the end of the lunar escape was a rare gem, diverging from his usual abrasive rants. Meeting Mr Hands in person was somewhat of a letdown, but more gigs from the sphinxian villain was welcome.

It's difficult to believe the DLC was produced by the same studio as the cliché and filth-filled dumpster fire that is the core game. The setting remains as disgusting as ever, with humanity locked in a dull and primitive state of neo-feudal corporate overlords or communes of plain-roaming barbarians, but Phantom Liberty redeems the price tag. If you find a way to skip to the DLC and just play the extra, do it: it is a real treat for any lovers of a spy drama - something Deux Ex tried and failed to do.

Edit: ending credits animation film was an outstanding tribute to the classic James Bond movies. Stellar.

AMAZING

Ah, “Phantom Liberty,” where the neon lights are brighter, the stakes are higher, and the glitches are… well, let’s just say they’re part of the charm. Imagine if James Bond, Keanu Reeves, and Idris Elba decided to throw a party in Night City, and you get to clean up the mess. That’s Phantom Liberty for you.

The expansion kicks off with the President of the New United States crash-landing in Dogtown. Yes, you read that right. Apparently, Air Force One now comes with a “crash here for plot development” button. You’re hired to rescue her, but not before you navigate through a maze of cybernetic baddies, morally ambiguous choices, and enough plot twists to make a pretzel jealous.

Idris Elba’s character, Solomon Reed, is the secret agent we all wish we could be. He’s suave, he’s mysterious, and he probably has a better skincare routine than you. Meanwhile, Keanu Reeves returns as Johnny Silverhand, still rocking that “I hate the system” vibe but with a touch more existential dread. It’s like watching your cool uncle go through a mid-life crisis, but with more explosions.

Dogtown itself is a marvel. It’s like someone took all the worst parts of a dystopian future and decided to make it a tourist attraction. The local wildlife includes cyber-enhanced gangsters and vending machines that might just try to sell you a grenade. But hey, at least the street food is to die for—literally.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment you’re making life-or-death decisions, the next you’re wondering why your character’s pants have suddenly disappeared. It’s all part of the Cyberpunk experience, folks. Embrace the chaos.

In conclusion, Phantom Liberty is the perfect blend of high-stakes drama, cybernetic mayhem, and unintentional comedy. It’s like a soap opera set in a dystopian future, and honestly, we wouldn’t have it any other way. So, grab your cyberdeck, put on your best trench coat, and dive into the madness. Just watch out for those vending machines.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!

It’s important to note that I am a massive fan of the original Frostpunk; it became my second most-played game at around 450 hours or so in the blink of an eye.
   With that said, I think this game has a lot of promise to it, something I hope to confirm with more play time. Overall, it’s a very different game than the original, and I think most of the changes are for the better. It feels so so nice to have the frost land be expanded in the way that it has, as it scratches the part of my brain that found intrigue imaging all the colonies from the original story mode interacting with one another. Granted, your settlements can end up pretty one-note, only producing primarily one resource, though granted they’re designed to do so, but it “feels” more like a community to me in a way that I appreciate. I do like how they’ve focused on more overarching goals in your week-to-week city functions, as it gives more of a focus on the balancing act of this environment as opposed to micro-managing the placements of buildings. Not to say that the latter is bad, but I think the former fits better with the setting being this much further in the timeline, which is a nice way to change the gameplay, I’d say.
   I think the tech tree and exploration are serviceable, frankly. Your exploration upgrades are basically pre-determined, at least in my short amount of time with the game, and the research nodes share a similarity with the original, that being a decent amount of fluff, meaning useless things to spend research time on. They’re both things I can live with about the game, and I feel they show promise for if I want to min-max the game like I did with the original.
   I will say, I have very mixed feelings about the gameplay modes available. I’ve currently finished the story mode and 2 of the 3 endless challenges, all on the easiest difficulty, so I’m both disappointed there’s no more “story” while excited that there’s so much more to do within the modes I currently have(that is to say, higher difficulties). Let it be know that this is after 20 hours of play, which, for a 60-odd dollar game (for the deluxe pre-order at least), I’m alright with considering how much more there is to do. The play sessions are something I have a bit of an issue with, though; it’s difficult to really feel rewarded after just an hour or two of play, meaning it’s not really feasible to pick it up and play like you could with some of the scenarios from the original.
   Honestly, if you’re looking for a casual game to pick up for an hour or two every now and then, I don’t think I can recommend this for you. But, then again, we don’t play Frostpunk for an easy time, lol. If you’re like me, a sweaty nerd who is okay with a long play session, go for it! I’ve had a bunch of fun with it already and can’t wait for the DLC. Even for the base game, I’d say $45 is pretty reasonable for everything you’re getting here.

A pretty solid sequel to Frostpunk 1. The balance is very wonky, with the early game being somewhat hard even on the lower difficulties and the late game being easy to the point of almost being boring, however apart from that i can't complain much about it. It follows the ideal sequel model in that it diverges enough to be unique and interesting yet still keeps several concepts from Frostpunk 1 and expands the story. The new political system is very fun and rewarding especially once you fully understand how it works. I do also like the idea of radicalism not inherently being a bad thing, as though it causes strife it isn't portrayed as morally evil, just controversial. I also like how each ideology has some truly bad ideas on how to run things that are almost objectively worse, so you have to weigh practicality and controversy.

Overall, a pretty solid game which does a lot good albeit with some bad 8/10

Summary:
Decent city sim that still retains the charm of the original. Push your people to work in terrible conditions for the good of the city. Performance / polish issues at launch but nothing game breaking, to be expected (sadly) from new releases nowadays. Negotiation system has lots of potential but feels underbaked at the moment.

6.5/10 wait until updates and patches come out.

My thoughts:
Pros:
All the little buildings and vehicles in your city are fun to look at, especially coming from the smaller scale of the original.

Hexagonal tiling system encourages careful planning to maximize the output of your districts and hubs. My next run will definitely be more planned out!

Expanded Frostland with new locations and riches to discover.

Cons (at time of writing):
[b] Performance in the end game is really bad, sound cuts out. [/b]

UI bugs and some typos. Nothing major but this really should have been polished pre-release. [spoiler] IEC VALLEY [/spoiler]

Some text obviously has placeholders for the faction/zeitgeist/law names, the bits of story and flavor text could be more customized to the topics / factions referenced.

Some buildings do not feel like they have distinct enough tradeoffs between the different versions. Building interactions and deconstruction is currently bugged at time of writing.

The negotiation system, while not barebones, feels underbaked. Research / construction promises are trivial to fulfill on easier difficulties.

Need ways to:
Cancel buildings / district construction if you pick the wrong thing by accident.
Quickly activate building abilities en masse / individually outside the district menus (like heaters in FP1).
Quickly increase and decrease the % of workers in a district outside the district menu

SPOILER ZONE:
[spoiler]you should not be able to negotiate on the "Peace Accords" proposal to win the reconciliation ending.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]civil war effects should slow / shut down more of your city. i find it hard to believe that 90% of the city can continue production while there is war in the streets.[/spoiler]

Frostpunk 2 takes everything I loved about the original and cranks it up to a whole new level. The scale is much larger, but instead of feeling overwhelming, it feels more immersive and strategic. There's so much more to do, and every decision feels heavier, with more meaningful choices that impact the game world in profound ways.

One of the biggest changes is how you now manage your city. Instead of placing individual buildings, you place districts that organically fill with buildings, almost like zoning in SimCity. You can still plop key structures inside those zones, which adds a whole new layer of strategy and makes the city feel more alive. It's not a remake, DLC, or Frostpunk 1.5—this is a true evolution of the series.

Faction tensions also add a new challenge that makes the game more difficult, but in a good way. Balancing the different groups in your city adds another level of depth to the decision-making process. Every choice now feels like it could ripple across the entire city.

The music and sound design are absolutely top-tier, pulling you even deeper into the harsh, frozen world. And the level of detail is astounding—whether it's the visuals or the small touches in the world, everything feels meticulously crafted.

If you enjoyed the first Frostpunk, you'll love this one even more. The improvements across the board—whether it's the expanded mechanics, larger scale, or more impactful storytelling—make Frostpunk 2 not just a worthy sequel, but a superior experience. Highly recommended!

Great sequel to an incredible game. Might not feel as memorable as the first one. but still, it's a great game and a worthy successor to an amazing franchise.

A worthy sequel that keeps the spirit of the first while elevating the gameplay to the next level!

It's what Darkest Dungeon 2 is to Darkest Dungeon 1 - it's familiar but different, and as a result both games are able to achieve different things (which I think is a more interesting approach than "the same game again but with more stuff").

I was initially a bit disappointed when I discovered you wouldn't spend the game micromanaging the generator and squeezing every second out of overdrive to prevent a single death. But as soon as I realized the game needed me to manage MULTIPLE colonies simultaneously and balance shared resources between them, I gasped at what a kick-ass feeling that gives you! You end up doing a lot of the same juggling acts as the first game, just abstracted into different scales (very crudely, it's like they took every number from the first game an added a x100 multiplier to it).

I agree with the comments that some of the intimacy is lost, but that's a natural consequence of moving the scope up. "A single death is a tragedy, a million deaths are a statistic" and all that. But what it lacks in personal intimacy is made up for in the need to make tough decisions that affect swathes of people. "Logic clearly dictates that the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few." 🖖🏽

I'm really enjoying my time so far in the sequel to one of my favourite games of all time, and if the planned DLC is anything like the first game, there's such a deep sandbox here with which to craft scenarios (not to mention the mods that are going to happen)!

It just isn't fun. The designers want you to go down VERY linear paths through a windy tech-tree that would be more pleasantly presented as a platformer or whatever. It's an excessively simple game: do what the designer had in mind and nothing else. But a million "options" are given to you, so the "meaning" is absolutely lost in the white noise.

Like the designers say: you will lose a lot.
As they don't say: arbitrarily, because you made good choices that weren't the ones we anticipated.
Example: I stocked up 100,000 coal for the winter, but because I upgraded my engine to accept oil, that coal was useless to me so everyone froze to death instead of just huddling around their backyard BBQs.

I'll mostly just be reinforcing what many of the other reviews are saying. This is not Frostpunk 1, but bigger and better. This is a new game, with the same setting, similar themes are atmosphere, etc., but this is a new game. I like this new game, others may not. I don't recommend simply buying this because you liked Frostpunk 1. Look at this like it's a fresh game and ask yourself if it looks like the kind of game for you.

And I don't think any of this is a problem. It's not like it's totally disconnected from Frostpunk 1. They wanted to take a crack at it from a totally different angle. Power to them. I wish more games companies did things like this. Take risks, try new ideas, see what happens. Easier said than done, of course.
Amazing sequel

A proper sequel. Takes everything from the first to a more grand scale. Abstracts away 'wood vs iron', for instance, in favor of factions and a council where laws are proposed and deals are made. Loving the gold accents in the menu and visuals. Soundtrack is gas. Yet these are only icing on the already delicious post-apocalyptic society-builder cake.

The game takes great strides to make things feel personal, as in how individuals in your society respond to events and feel. This, despite many reviewers claiming that they feel disconnected from individual workers, for example. My opinion is that what these reviewers want is another Frostpunk expansion, and that's fine. Just don't miss out on this incredibly well done sequel.

I didn’t expect to like this game. As an old-school Diablo 2 fan, I was skeptical, but with all the hype and seeing it on sale, I decided to give it a try. Somehow, the game sucks you in. It’s like watching grandma at the casino—every slot machine is hitting. Some of the payouts are pennies, and some are much bigger, but the idea that you might hit big or miss out on the next great item or event keeps you hooked.

There’s a lot of flash and bang, action-packed gore to keep things interesting, and plenty of ways to build your character. You can easily spend hours just sitting at your stash, or googling new ways to improve a single build. I wouldn’t say it’s the best game out there, but it definitely does the job when it comes to keeping you entertained.

I held off on buying this game for a long time because I do not want to support the idea of a battle pass.  I find they often ruin great games.  I eventually gave in and bought this during a trial period and really enjoyed it, so much so that I bought it, despite my grumblings against it.  Since then I've enjoyed it, despite the battle pass, which only has cosmetic rewards.  I still don't love the idea of a battle pass but the fact that the battle pass is purely cosmetic helps water it down for me.  Another thing that helps greatly is that the free tier of armor looks really amazing.  They didn't skimp on armor cosmetics to try and guide people towards buying cosmetics, which is a big plus and actually the only reason I would recommend the game.  As far as game play goes, it's been really fun.  End game is a little complicated and to get anywhere you have to follow someone else's build but that's pretty standard for RPGs these days.

Monkey King's Reign: The Global Impact of 'Black Myth: Wukong'
By KAI WOOD|Aug 26,2024
Chongqing - Black Myth: Wukong, a Chinese AAA game, has taken the gaming world by storm, smashing sales records and captivating millions of players with its breathtaking combat, stellar production quality, and unforgettable boss fights. Despite some skepticism from Western media outlets like IGN, the game has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from gamers around the globe. To explore what makes this game so special, Bridging News reached out to some Western gamers in China.

The New Evolution of Action RPG: 'Black Myth: Wukong'
Jacob Kapustinski, a dedicated gamer from Connecticut who is now living in Chongqing, China,  shared his thoughts on what makes this game stand out. 

Jacob's gaming journey began almost as soon as he could hold a controller. "I've been gaming my entire life," he recalls. "I was sitting on my dad’s lap, controller in hand, by the time I was three." His move to China seven years ago broadened his gaming interests. "Moving here, I've started appreciating different gaming styles, especially Chinese RPGs like Black Myth: Wukong." Jacob’s enthusiasm for the game is evident. "When the first trailer dropped five years ago, I was hooked. It was clear this game would be something special, and it hasn’t disappointed."


A Game That Lives Up to the Hype


Incredible cover art for the new AAA Game Black Myth: Wukong (Photo by Game Science)


"This game lives up to every bit of its hype," Jacob states. "It’s visually stunning, with tight controls and an engaging story. It's definitely China’s big entry into the AAA market." With about 30 hours of gameplay, Jacob is convinced of its impact. "It’s the new evolution of action RPGs, blending the best elements of Souls-like games with unique Chinese mythology. It’s a game that both challenges and immerses."

To get a sense of the local reaction, Huang HuiJing, a young man in Chongqing, thought of it as a hardcore Chinese gamer. "Every character has his own story, and it's a deeply Chinese story that is very meaningful to Chinese people. It's amazing. My friends and I, we all love it very much," he said before quickly returning to finish his boss fight. 

Showcasing Chongqing on a Global Stage


The UNESCO World Heritage Site Dazu Buddhist Sculptures are brought to the incredible and stunning fantasy world in Black Myth: WuKong (Photo by Game Science)


What sets Black Myth: Wukong apart is its deep cultural roots. Set against the backdrop of iconic Chinese locations like Chongqing’s Baoding Mountains and the Dazu Buddhist sculptures, the game weaves real-world beauty into its fantasy. "It’s fantasy, sure, but it’s so deeply rooted in real places that it makes you appreciate China’s culture and landscapes," Jacob explains. "This game is like a love letter to China. It’s going to make people around the world curious about these places, about Chongqing."

Igniting Conversations and Curiosity
Beyond its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Black Myth: Wukong is sparking deeper cultural conversations. James Mitchell, a Scottish teacher who lived in Chongqing before moving to the sunny beaches of Sanya, has noticed a shift in how people engage with Chinese mythology. "The game has spurred a lot of conversations about Chinese mythology," he observes. "My wife, who usually isn’t interested in gaming, is now fully engaged. She explains the mythical creatures and the rich lore behind them. It’s fascinating to see how the game brings these ancient stories to life, resonating with both Chinese and international audiences."

For James, Black Myth: Wukong's impact extends far beyond entertainment. "It’s a modern platform that not only entertains but also educates," he says. The game acts as an eye-opener for many players, offering a glimpse into history and mythology that they might not have explored otherwise."

James is eager to bring these discussions into his classroom. "I’m looking forward to encouraging students to explore and express their opinions on the game," he adds, "and to delve into the rich cultural heritage it portrays." This educational potential highlights Black Myth: Wukong's unique role in bridging cultural gaps and promoting a deeper understanding of Chinese mythology.

Facing Criticism Head-On


Asmongold, a top YouTube influencer known for his reactions and comments on new games, has heartily endorsed Black Myth: Wukong (Photo from Asmongold)


Despite its success, Black Myth: Wukong hasn’t escaped criticism, particularly from Western media. Jacob shrugs off the negativity. "Critics will always find something to nitpick, but the players love it. That’s what counts." YouTube personality Asmongold chimed in on the controversy, suggesting that the criticisms from outlets like IGN might stem from commercial motives rather than genuine concern. "They're more concerned with staying relevant than with what gamers actually want," Asmongold argues. "And gamers want Wukong."

A New Era for Chinese Gaming


Black Myth: Wukong, China's first AAA action-adventure game, has broken all records for single-player games already and shows no signs of slowing down (Photo from Game Science)

Jacob is excited about what Black Myth: Wukong means for the future. "China's mostly been known for mobile games, but this changes everything. Now, the world knows that China can produce big, high-quality, culturally rich games. This is just the beginning," he emphasizes. "This game shows that China is in the big leagues now, and it's only going to get better. We’re going to see more great games, a lot more like this, more China-made and Chinese culture games."

Black Myth: Wukong is more than a game; it's a cultural phenomenon, bridging gaps between East and West. As Jacob enthusiastically notes, "This isn't just about gaming—it's about sharing our stories, our culture, and showing the world what we can do."


Jorah Kai, the author of Kai's Diary, Amos the Amazing, and the soon-to-be-released A Sun Also Rises on Cthulhu, is both a big fan of action games and Chinese culture. Here, he stands on the Great Wall of China, protecting it against monsters and those who would blemish Sun Wukong's great legacy. (Photo by Jorah Kai)

Forced to make psn account. Then it made me log in manually instead of auto-logging me in after making it (it's 2024 Sony come on). Already annoyed but it's fine, once and done I thought. NOPE.

It asked me to verify my account from email omg... but yay I saw a "do this later" option which I clicked on. This basically ended the game. Wow. Why are you offering this if it's a lie?

Reloaded game. Opened internet browser and verified stupid email for Sony. Tabbed over to the game and it wouldn't open. After maybe 20 seconds it crashed and Steam gave me a pop up error crash message. So sony PSN account nonsense crashed my game.

Reloaded game. Quite irritated at this point. I had to manually log in again to PSN. It asked me to verify account but I was able to click on "already verified" to get past that. FINALLY I thought... NOPE.

It asked me some annoying questions and terms and data crap but I saw a "do this later" button which I clicked on once again because this shouldn't matter I thought, I should be able to do this later in Settings or something. This ended the game again................................

I reloaded the game and guess what, had to manually log in AGAIN. So damn mad at this point.

I ignored the stupid "do this later" button which should've never existed in the first place because you literally cannot play if you click on it.

Finally got to the damn start screen. I went into settings and maxed everything out as usual. 4090/7950x3d/64gb. Game crashed in settings. I confirmed amd and nvidia drivers were up to date, which they were. Reloaded game.

Finally after like a half hour of bullshit I'm able to play. Thanks Sony! Negative review until the end of time from me.

In the future, any game requiring a PSN account from me will get a negative review even if the game blows my mind.
