I'll mostly just be reinforcing what many of the other reviews are saying. This is not Frostpunk 1, but bigger and better. This is a new game, with the same setting, similar themes are atmosphere, etc., but this is a new game. I like this new game, others may not. I don't recommend simply buying this because you liked Frostpunk 1. Look at this like it's a fresh game and ask yourself if it looks like the kind of game for you.

And I don't think any of this is a problem. It's not like it's totally disconnected from Frostpunk 1. They wanted to take a crack at it from a totally different angle. Power to them. I wish more games companies did things like this. Take risks, try new ideas, see what happens. Easier said than done, of course.
Amazing sequel

A proper sequel. Takes everything from the first to a more grand scale. Abstracts away 'wood vs iron', for instance, in favor of factions and a council where laws are proposed and deals are made. Loving the gold accents in the menu and visuals. Soundtrack is gas. Yet these are only icing on the already delicious post-apocalyptic society-builder cake.

The game takes great strides to make things feel personal, as in how individuals in your society respond to events and feel. This, despite many reviewers claiming that they feel disconnected from individual workers, for example. My opinion is that what these reviewers want is another Frostpunk expansion, and that's fine. Just don't miss out on this incredibly well done sequel.

Monkey King's Reign: The Global Impact of 'Black Myth: Wukong'
By KAI WOOD|Aug 26,2024
Chongqing - Black Myth: Wukong, a Chinese AAA game, has taken the gaming world by storm, smashing sales records and captivating millions of players with its breathtaking combat, stellar production quality, and unforgettable boss fights. Despite some skepticism from Western media outlets like IGN, the game has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from gamers around the globe. To explore what makes this game so special, Bridging News reached out to some Western gamers in China.

The New Evolution of Action RPG: 'Black Myth: Wukong'
Jacob Kapustinski, a dedicated gamer from Connecticut who is now living in Chongqing, China,  shared his thoughts on what makes this game stand out. 

Jacob's gaming journey began almost as soon as he could hold a controller. "I've been gaming my entire life," he recalls. "I was sitting on my dad’s lap, controller in hand, by the time I was three." His move to China seven years ago broadened his gaming interests. "Moving here, I've started appreciating different gaming styles, especially Chinese RPGs like Black Myth: Wukong." Jacob’s enthusiasm for the game is evident. "When the first trailer dropped five years ago, I was hooked. It was clear this game would be something special, and it hasn’t disappointed."


A Game That Lives Up to the Hype


Incredible cover art for the new AAA Game Black Myth: Wukong (Photo by Game Science)


"This game lives up to every bit of its hype," Jacob states. "It’s visually stunning, with tight controls and an engaging story. It's definitely China’s big entry into the AAA market." With about 30 hours of gameplay, Jacob is convinced of its impact. "It’s the new evolution of action RPGs, blending the best elements of Souls-like games with unique Chinese mythology. It’s a game that both challenges and immerses."

To get a sense of the local reaction, Huang HuiJing, a young man in Chongqing, thought of it as a hardcore Chinese gamer. "Every character has his own story, and it's a deeply Chinese story that is very meaningful to Chinese people. It's amazing. My friends and I, we all love it very much," he said before quickly returning to finish his boss fight. 

Showcasing Chongqing on a Global Stage


The UNESCO World Heritage Site Dazu Buddhist Sculptures are brought to the incredible and stunning fantasy world in Black Myth: WuKong (Photo by Game Science)


What sets Black Myth: Wukong apart is its deep cultural roots. Set against the backdrop of iconic Chinese locations like Chongqing’s Baoding Mountains and the Dazu Buddhist sculptures, the game weaves real-world beauty into its fantasy. "It’s fantasy, sure, but it’s so deeply rooted in real places that it makes you appreciate China’s culture and landscapes," Jacob explains. "This game is like a love letter to China. It’s going to make people around the world curious about these places, about Chongqing."

Igniting Conversations and Curiosity
Beyond its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Black Myth: Wukong is sparking deeper cultural conversations. James Mitchell, a Scottish teacher who lived in Chongqing before moving to the sunny beaches of Sanya, has noticed a shift in how people engage with Chinese mythology. "The game has spurred a lot of conversations about Chinese mythology," he observes. "My wife, who usually isn’t interested in gaming, is now fully engaged. She explains the mythical creatures and the rich lore behind them. It’s fascinating to see how the game brings these ancient stories to life, resonating with both Chinese and international audiences."

For James, Black Myth: Wukong's impact extends far beyond entertainment. "It’s a modern platform that not only entertains but also educates," he says. The game acts as an eye-opener for many players, offering a glimpse into history and mythology that they might not have explored otherwise."

James is eager to bring these discussions into his classroom. "I’m looking forward to encouraging students to explore and express their opinions on the game," he adds, "and to delve into the rich cultural heritage it portrays." This educational potential highlights Black Myth: Wukong's unique role in bridging cultural gaps and promoting a deeper understanding of Chinese mythology.

Facing Criticism Head-On


Asmongold, a top YouTube influencer known for his reactions and comments on new games, has heartily endorsed Black Myth: Wukong (Photo from Asmongold)


Despite its success, Black Myth: Wukong hasn’t escaped criticism, particularly from Western media. Jacob shrugs off the negativity. "Critics will always find something to nitpick, but the players love it. That’s what counts." YouTube personality Asmongold chimed in on the controversy, suggesting that the criticisms from outlets like IGN might stem from commercial motives rather than genuine concern. "They're more concerned with staying relevant than with what gamers actually want," Asmongold argues. "And gamers want Wukong."

A New Era for Chinese Gaming


Black Myth: Wukong, China's first AAA action-adventure game, has broken all records for single-player games already and shows no signs of slowing down (Photo from Game Science)

Jacob is excited about what Black Myth: Wukong means for the future. "China's mostly been known for mobile games, but this changes everything. Now, the world knows that China can produce big, high-quality, culturally rich games. This is just the beginning," he emphasizes. "This game shows that China is in the big leagues now, and it's only going to get better. We’re going to see more great games, a lot more like this, more China-made and Chinese culture games."

Black Myth: Wukong is more than a game; it's a cultural phenomenon, bridging gaps between East and West. As Jacob enthusiastically notes, "This isn't just about gaming—it's about sharing our stories, our culture, and showing the world what we can do."


Jorah Kai, the author of Kai's Diary, Amos the Amazing, and the soon-to-be-released A Sun Also Rises on Cthulhu, is both a big fan of action games and Chinese culture. Here, he stands on the Great Wall of China, protecting it against monsters and those who would blemish Sun Wukong's great legacy. (Photo by Jorah Kai)

Forced to make psn account. Then it made me log in manually instead of auto-logging me in after making it (it's 2024 Sony come on). Already annoyed but it's fine, once and done I thought. NOPE.

It asked me to verify my account from email omg... but yay I saw a "do this later" option which I clicked on. This basically ended the game. Wow. Why are you offering this if it's a lie?

Reloaded game. Opened internet browser and verified stupid email for Sony. Tabbed over to the game and it wouldn't open. After maybe 20 seconds it crashed and Steam gave me a pop up error crash message. So sony PSN account nonsense crashed my game.

Reloaded game. Quite irritated at this point. I had to manually log in again to PSN. It asked me to verify account but I was able to click on "already verified" to get past that. FINALLY I thought... NOPE.

It asked me some annoying questions and terms and data crap but I saw a "do this later" button which I clicked on once again because this shouldn't matter I thought, I should be able to do this later in Settings or something. This ended the game again................................

I reloaded the game and guess what, had to manually log in AGAIN. So damn mad at this point.

I ignored the stupid "do this later" button which should've never existed in the first place because you literally cannot play if you click on it.

Finally got to the damn start screen. I went into settings and maxed everything out as usual. 4090/7950x3d/64gb. Game crashed in settings. I confirmed amd and nvidia drivers were up to date, which they were. Reloaded game.

Finally after like a half hour of bullshit I'm able to play. Thanks Sony! Negative review until the end of time from me.

In the future, any game requiring a PSN account from me will get a negative review even if the game blows my mind.

God of war Ragnarok is a rare type of sequel in the sense that its better than the first game in almost every way. The combat is much more refined to deliver a similar yet more polished experience than the 2018 game. The story itself is a very gripping and enthralling ride that I havent even finished yet despite me having almost 30 hours on the game and im just barely entering the final act. The side missions are very interesting and give some good lore about the areas you explore some of them even relating to characters Kratos and Atreus have encountered before, some of the rewards feel a bit lackluster at times but the game is typically pretty fair with the loot you get. Speaking of side content, there are a plethera of hidden bosses that i've encountered that if succeeding against them can easily get you a lot of xp and hacksilver, the boss fights are challenging yet fun that also feature a lot of different mechanics. Exploring more of the 9 realms is a journey in itself with each realm having a vibrant and unique look and feel, the graphics on this game are very good and sony delivered a very solid PC port so props to them. All in all id give this game a solid 9.5/10 so far, the only critique i could even have for it is that i wish the game was longer however, they were kind enough to make the free Valhalla DLC which is a roguelike experience in the post game that you can get a lot of time out of in itself.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.

Cyberpunk isn't a good game by any measure and the less of its setting leaks into the real world, the better but if you do end up playing it, get Phantom Liberty and ignore the main game to the best of your ability.
The dlc is its own thing pretty much with an extra ending of its own, which has the added benefit of skipping the remainder of the core vidya.

Now, onto the good things: the script, the pacing, the dialogues, the execution of a properly polished thriller. The DLC adds some extra missions for old fixers. Fetch quests aside, the quest are good too, adding depth and nuance to the NPCs. Though the most important is the selection of end-game choices you're presented with. Between wetwork, dubious loyalties and complex motivations of dramatis personaes, someone did their homework on intelligence services so a lot of it offers a very authentic experience. A lot of times you leave feeling dirty - because that is the nature of the work. My only criticism is you couldn't off Meyers (it'd be tons of fun, I think), but otherwise it's next to excellent. Johnny's dialogue at the end of the lunar escape was a rare gem, diverging from his usual abrasive rants. Meeting Mr Hands in person was somewhat of a letdown, but more gigs from the sphinxian villain was welcome.

It's difficult to believe the DLC was produced by the same studio as the cliché and filth-filled dumpster fire that is the core game. The setting remains as disgusting as ever, with humanity locked in a dull and primitive state of neo-feudal corporate overlords or communes of plain-roaming barbarians, but Phantom Liberty redeems the price tag. If you find a way to skip to the DLC and just play the extra, do it: it is a real treat for any lovers of a spy drama - something Deux Ex tried and failed to do.

Edit: ending credits animation film was an outstanding tribute to the classic James Bond movies. Stellar.

Ah, “Phantom Liberty,” where the neon lights are brighter, the stakes are higher, and the glitches are… well, let’s just say they’re part of the charm. Imagine if James Bond, Keanu Reeves, and Idris Elba decided to throw a party in Night City, and you get to clean up the mess. That’s Phantom Liberty for you.

The expansion kicks off with the President of the New United States crash-landing in Dogtown. Yes, you read that right. Apparently, Air Force One now comes with a “crash here for plot development” button. You’re hired to rescue her, but not before you navigate through a maze of cybernetic baddies, morally ambiguous choices, and enough plot twists to make a pretzel jealous.

Idris Elba’s character, Solomon Reed, is the secret agent we all wish we could be. He’s suave, he’s mysterious, and he probably has a better skincare routine than you. Meanwhile, Keanu Reeves returns as Johnny Silverhand, still rocking that “I hate the system” vibe but with a touch more existential dread. It’s like watching your cool uncle go through a mid-life crisis, but with more explosions.

Dogtown itself is a marvel. It’s like someone took all the worst parts of a dystopian future and decided to make it a tourist attraction. The local wildlife includes cyber-enhanced gangsters and vending machines that might just try to sell you a grenade. But hey, at least the street food is to die for—literally.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment you’re making life-or-death decisions, the next you’re wondering why your character’s pants have suddenly disappeared. It’s all part of the Cyberpunk experience, folks. Embrace the chaos.

In conclusion, Phantom Liberty is the perfect blend of high-stakes drama, cybernetic mayhem, and unintentional comedy. It’s like a soap opera set in a dystopian future, and honestly, we wouldn’t have it any other way. So, grab your cyberdeck, put on your best trench coat, and dive into the madness. Just watch out for those vending machines.

Tiny Glade offers a breath of fresh air for those seeking a serene, low-pressure gaming experience. Set in a whimsical medieval world, the game invites you to design charming landscapes, building walls, towers, and other structures that evoke the timeless allure of the Middle Ages. The graphics are nothing short of stunning, with each stone, tree, and blade of grass beautifully rendered to create a warm, visually rich atmosphere. The art style strikes a perfect balance between realism and fantasy, drawing you into the tranquil setting with a painterly feel that delights the senses.

One of the game's standout features is its intuitive and easy-to-master controls. Whether you’re placing stones or designing pathways, everything feels smooth and responsive, allowing your creativity to flow without interruption. This simplicity makes it an ideal canvas for players who enjoy the art of design, offering a stress-free way to construct and beautify the world around you.

The absence of complex objectives might be a downside for players seeking deeper engagement, but Tiny Glade shines precisely because of its simplicity. It is less about grand adventures and more about offering a peaceful space for artistic expression. Daily themes and inspirations guide you, giving just the right nudge to kickstart your creativity, making it perfect for those who find themselves staring at a blank canvas unsure of where to begin.

However, it’s important to set your expectations correctly. Tiny Glade isn’t about intense gameplay or deep storylines; it’s about creating and relaxing. For players seeking a break from more demanding titles, this game provides a calming escape. That said, it is not without its limitations. Currently, it struggles to run smoothly on low-end laptops, which may result in occasional performance issues. While it remains playable, the game doesn't offer much in terms of graphic settings, so players with less powerful machines may need to accept some visual limitations.

In conclusion, Tiny Glade excels at what it sets out to do: provide a peaceful, creative outlet in a beautifully crafted world. For those who value relaxation and artistry over action and story, it is a delightful gem. Just be aware that it requires a relatively strong system to fully appreciate its graphical charm.

Methodical combat that rewards good decision-making like classic Dark Souls. Although unlike Dark Souls parrying is basically required just like Sekiro except the timing is a bit harder. Although I am a Souls veteran, I struggled immensely on the first somewhat challenging boss because it was pretty much a test of how well you could parry as simply whiff punishing between his attacks did very little damage. So parrying was the only way to get big damage by breaking his posture and riposting him. Once you master that, you've "gotten good" at LoP. There is also the rally system from Bloodborne, which just lets you regain most of the damage taken from blocking if you attack the opponent a few times after. The overall game has the same amount of polish as FromSoftware games, though it has a surprising amount of DNA from Code Vein in the sound and visual effects, and some mechanics like sliding down ladders and interacting with more things at your home base. So far I love it!

Lies of P is a game that was truly fantastic for it's first few hours, drops off a bit by midgame, and becomes an infuriating mess by chapter 7/11.  The first part of this review is for the general game, the second part is the threshold where I accepted it wasn't worth continuing.

Pros:
1.  The Legion arm mechanic is pretty cool.  Essentially preset secondary equipments that can be upgraded to add new passives to them.  Examples include a staggering grapple hook, a charge up electric blast, a landmine summoner, and a a retaliatory shield.  Legion arms allow you to get a boost against harder foes that your weapon proves insufficient for.
2.  Parry mechanics.  Depending on what kind of enemy your fighting, a perfect parry will either help stagger them for a combo hit or help shatter their weapon, reducing attack variety and damage.
3.  Specters act as boss assists if you're frustrated or unable to defeat a boss.  It's a pretty big help if your too frustrated.

Cons:
1.  Underwhelming soundtrack.  The only music in the game outside of the gramophone is against bosses, and they all sound pretty similar.
2.  Finite resources.  There's only one copy of each weapon, armor, and amulet, with no way to get more.  If you sold or missed an item, it's gone forever, the entire playthrough.  Quartz, the skilltree material, can't even cover half the skilltree without running out for the rest of the playthrough.  Cranks, allowing you to tinker with weapon scaling, are also finite, discouraging experimentation.  Consumables have to be slowly grinded for until chapter 5 when you can buy them.
3.  Rushed choices.  Any time the game has you make a narrative choice, it gives you about 6 seconds before automatically selecting whatever your cursor touched last, leaving no time to think anything through.  This leads to decisions feeling incoherent and shallow.
4.  Lack of information.  The game doesn't tell you what three of your six stats even do, making the early game confusing.  Status effects only tell you what they do once they've killed you.

Last part of my review is unfairness.  Up until Elysian Boulevard, the game does quite well with dying being your fault rather than cheap shots or instant death.  Once you reach the boss there, you have your first instance of simply full on stun locking you with no escape method.  Once you trudge your way through that, you soon hit the swamp monster, with the ability to also kill you in one inescapable combo, but with the addition of being far too durable to kill with consumables and shredding your specter.  Outside of bosses, several things lead to being unfair.  Several points have enemy locations that you can't reasonably deal with, leading to barely avoidable damage.

Keep in mind that this is my first souls like, so I can't compare it well to others.  I do enjoy difficult games such as Dead Cells and Celeste, but difficult and unfair are rather different things.

With the DLC on the horizon, I would like to share a few words about this game.... or maybe just one word....."masterpiece".

As someone who's never played a Dark Souls game, this was my first Souls-like experience that I actually finished. I own Elden Ring, but I never completed it because I got too lost in its open-world concept. However, this game was an amazing introduction to the genre, especially considering it comes from a smaller studio, not a massive corporation.

The story is captivating, and the game does a great job guiding you through it. The voice acting is absolutely incredible—most games have at least a bit of cringe in their dialogue, but not this one. The performances are top-notch.

Combat is really fun and rewarding. Parrying can break enemies' weapons, and you can combine different weapons and handles (I mostly used boss weapons throughout the game). I didn’t find the game overly difficult either—you can even beat some bosses with throwable items, and certain bosses allow you to summon an aid, which is super helpful.

The music is also insane. It’s one of the highlights of the game for sure. After beating it, I immediately wanted to start another playthrough, but I’ve heard that DLC and a sequel have been announced, so I’m waiting for that. When the DLC drops, I’m definitely doing another run with a new weapon setup.

If you’ve never played a Souls game, I really believe this is a great entry point into the genre. I highly recommend it!

Given the fact that this is a game built almost entirely on parrying, it's frustrating when you can't stop a chain of actions to parry or dodge. Also any hit seems to slightly stagger P. For a split second you can't move and for just slightly longer you can't parry or dodge. Not a problem for most of the game, but for the very fast bosses chaining attacks, it's annoying you can see P not reacting to your input as another attack comes in. Yet for the most part, your attacks don't have the same effect.

There are minor issues with it such as bosses that jump very high in the air, yet the camera angle cannot look straight up. In some places it's like ledges are covered in grease. It's possible to be pinned against a wall or object by an enemy and have no way out, it's effectively a death sentence with certain enemies.

*Minor spoilers*
Most of the bosses are fun with good cut scenes.
3 of them are not fun. The King of Puppets, Laxasia and the Nameless puppet.
There is clearly a reason the achievement % drops off at each of these.
The times I beat them, it was luck of the draw of how aggressive the boss was feeling that round.

Sometimes it feels like that game goes out of it's way to kill you if you do "too well" and get close to killing the boss quickly in the first few rounds. You'll soon be punished with an onslaught. Yet if you just stand there and practice parrying, you don't get the same intense beating.

For the fights with the spectre, for me just using a single HP re-gen wish on it worked well to keep the boss distracted for longer. Other wishes are okay, but nowhere near as impactful as simply having two of you in the battle for longer.

Save throwing items until you have the boss down to <10% health, then use them to help finish it quick. Otherwise don't bother using them, they're effectively a limited resource before you'll have to go out farming for them. 

I beat each of the above 3 by using fable arts and throwables in those last few moments.
Get good and you will find gold.

You're a puppet whose lies shape the story and the outcome—so keep your nose (and blade) sharp. It's a fresh spin on familiar mechanics with a gothic charm that'll keep you hooked, even when you're rage-quitting... for the 10th time.

Describing my experience with Lies of P as simply another 'souls-like ARPG' would be entirely reductive to the amount of passion & attention-to-detail presented by the teams at Neowiz and Round8 Studio. Lies of P sees you lead as Gepetto's puppet in a twisted, gloomy take on the folktale of Pinocchio. Waking up in an eerie train station, you soon make your way outside to the city of Krat, where a sudden trigger in the puppets causes a haunting massacre that sets the tone for the rest of the game.

     On that note, atmosphere is the name. Hotel Krat is your central hub, and it quickly evolved from being a brief trip to level up my weapons into a safe retreat where I could listen to a vibrant soundtrack in the background as I spoke with the many charismatic faces that made up this iconic location. It's not just the hub area - everything from oil-lined streets to infested cathedrals, the immense amount of detail present within the level design itself across most of the chapters is incredibly impressive. Whether it was my first playthrough or my sixth, I could not help but immerse myself in all of the intricately placed bodies & texts around the city that truly cements this game as an all-time example of how to do proper environmental storytelling within linear experiences. Neowiz and Round8 really wear the inspiration on their sleeves with the worldbuilding here and it's very well executed. (Note: it runs flawlessly for me on an upper-end rig, but even on my steam deck it is the best performing game I own. It's also very nicely balanced and well-paced. I would say I preferred the difficulty around launch, as it really heightened my enjoyment of this game in a unique way because of how challenging it was. But it's still a decent challenge and NG+ definitely brought that difficulty back.) 

     Combat is really where Lies of P hits all of its strides for me. As a fan of FromSoftware's 'soulsborne' entries for the better part of a decade, I believe Lies of P implements so many positive spins on their formula that I would recommend this over the traditional souls games to any player, regardless of experience (well... maybe play Sekiro.) For example, one of my favorite mechanics is pulse recharge, which allows you to gain one more charge to your healing consumable if you are at zero. This feature would change the entire dynamic of so many of my fights in an instant. Maybe I'm playing defensively, I've got two more heals and 60% of the boss's health left; in scenarios like this, every single time I reached zero heals, my brain would switch to aggression immediately in the hopes of regaining a charge and feel more 'comfortable.' I cannot speak to everyone's experience, but this mechanic made me a better player over time as I was PUSHED into being more active in my gameplay and subsequently rewarded with the most satisfying sound effect I've heard since the Halo CE shield recharge as a single pulse cell materializes right back into your upper belt. 

     Another great feature to the combat sandbox is the ability to assemble weapons. This is the single-most innovative design choice that Lies of P offers. Every weapon comes in two distinct parts, the blade tip and the handle. Each part has their respective stats; however, you can alter the handle to scale off of different stats than the ones it drops with. This opens up a lot of customization and encourages player experimentation, because at no extra-cost, your entire moveset and ability options can change in a matter of seconds. I myself am a Guts sword girl through and through, but even I felt compelled to experiment and eventually beat the game with my own ridiculous combinations. (Note: For me, this self-expression was VERY important in my enjoyment of the game, and I think it's a great innovation to the souls combat formula to allow your players to test out ANY weapon handle's moveset with... every other weapon's blade. Admittedly boss weapons are restricted from being customized and the scaling of both parts' stab/slash stat means that your options for good damage are inherently limited, but it offers so much freedom regardless that I would not mind seeing it return in the sequel.) 

     Story is the point I want to end this off on. For as long as I have cherished Bloodborne's lore, the original trilogy's lore, etc. I have never actually felt connected to the events of the stories presented in souls-like games. There's always been a strange disconnect for me being able to enjoy the challenge of the gameplay rather than caring about the story. I can say Lies of P genuinely moved me in a way no other games in this subgenre have. I believe the most obvious explanation for this is the greater emphasis on dialogue and player onboarding that Lies of P engages in. There is a real sense here with the amount of dialogue you'll receive from a character off-screen during gameplay or in the middle of a boss fight that Neowiz really wanted to make players feel INVOLVED in the big character moments as they are happening, rather than reading about them from a lore description (which is also a method of storytelling present with a lot to read up on that is engaging.) To be clear, I have no issue with this, but I really prefer the focus on character engaging with me, the truths/lies you decide to tell them, and the almost-immediate consequences those decisions can have as they relay their reactions back to you. You can ignore or fight multiple bosses by making a simple decision. I like that. The narrative throughline that is happening above all of the character stories is decently executed, but the character quests is really where Lies of P shines (shoutout to Arlecchino.) Everyone is voice acted phenomenally, and this could not be a Lies of P review without making mention of how pivotal this game's original soundtrack is to the overall experience. The music feels tied to the characters' stories, as many records you can play back at Hotel Krat are received from quest completions. This makes even something as seemingly trivial as playing a record on a record player feel rewarding in itself, as you learn more about an NPC's journey through this world or simply enjoy a great tune in the background. 

     This has become my comfort game, and affectionately so. That doesn't mean it is devoid of things I disliked, as the final area of the game, Arche Abbey, has got to be the single-most tedious level I have played in recent memory. Running through this moody grey wasteland to a grey tower with grey floors and repeated enemies from throughout the entire game got tiring incredibly fast, and it's a shame that the area with this game's pinnacle challenges is also so uninspired in its design. Additionally, I do not think the armor system, dubbed "Defense parts," is particularly exciting. I think this could be fleshed out a little more, but finding more parts throughout the game is almost never exciting because they are always going to be better than your previous find, and they do not change any part of your puppet's appearance. I do like the cosmetics available here, but I definitely prefer the more free-form style of armor expression in other souls-likes. The legion arm system is probably the most disappointing aspect for me, delivering options to customize your limb similar to the prosthetic tools in Sekiro. I do not like the implementation in this game because it feels stiff to me. This is not something I have the knowledge to explain away, but it feels very restricted and with the low amount of legion I always have, it just left a lot to be desired for me because I mainly relied on parrying and counterattacking. 

     Despite my negatives, I adore this game. At the time of writing I have unlocked everything pre-DLC and waiting in anticipation for it as well as the recently announced sequel. If you've ever got a weekend to knockout a surprisingly compelling souls-like, this is absolutely the one for you.
Game's so nice, I bought it twice. Already finished multiple times on Xbox and it's a blast! Runs smooth, looks great, plays great. Can't wait to see what they do with the DLC and inevitable sequel.

This game is fantastic. Hands down the best souls-like not made my Fromsoft.

Combat is fast-paced and has a bit of a learning curve, but is extremely satisfying once it clicks. Learning when to parry vs block, attack with a weapon vs throwbacks vs weapon art was fun and engaging. 

It also looks great and runs smoothly. Even on the Steam Deck with decent graphic settings, I was easily keeping 60 FPS.

Some people have criticized it for not being as open world as a game like Elden Ring, but I see that as a positive aspect of Lies of P. Being able to have a more linear path made the gameplay tight and paced well. It also never felt like it overstayed it's welcome, like I wind up feeling about many open world games.

This is the only game I've ever been motivated to 100% and can't wait for the DLC and sequel.

If you're on the fence, buy this game immediately.

Even though I`ve only played the recent FF games like FF 15 and 7 remake, I`ll give my opinion. The game in general feels good, there isn`t as much complexity as FF15 in combat, but a more straight forward approach, something the hardcore FF15 fans may be disappointed by. The story in my eyes, isn`t a 10/10, but it`s enjoyable. Likeable characters, and party members. The dlcs however are lackluster. Echos of the fallen, though it is half the price of The rising tide, it`s just a single dungeon with little to enrich the story further. The rising tide is a step up, and has one of the cooler and more difficult Ifrit fights which is something many should look forward to. 7.5/10

SPOILERS BELOW!!!
For me the ending is what puts this game down. The talk with Jill about the moon, and the constant reminding of don`t go dying on us Clive spoils the ending way too much. Not only that, but I was hoping for a better ending, as this is just the ending of FF15 done all over again. Using the crystal, and vanquishing the darkness or blight which it`s called here. The hero dies alone after saying goodbye to all his loved ones, only that Noctis was reunited with his loved ones when he died. I don`t see why every ending has to be a sad and lonely one for our hero.

What I've been able to play has been stunning.  The story is immersive, soundtrack is emotionally perfect, and the world itself is breathtaking.  
  However it's such a disappointment that the FPS drops absolutely murder this game.  
I'm running this on an Nvidia GeForce RTX 3060 with 16 GB ram and an Intel Core i7 Processor.  I have tried manipulating the graphics settings on all levels, from low to ultra, which i should be able to run with ease.  I have turned off all special lighting effects.  Sometimes the game works perfectly with them for quite some time before it starts stuttering.  Sometimes I'll turn the game on and it's sputtering and skating from the get go, and on other occasions I can get perhaps an hour and a half of game play in before it drops  down below 30 FPS for no reason at all.  My computer is not over heating.   I have the AI set to performance temperature control.  I have tried everything, even making sure that the computer itself is choosing the correct GPU to use when I run the game.

   I've been looking forward to this for some time now, and I don't think I'll get to finish it until this gets an update.  Until then, this is gonna be a not recommended for me, save your money and wait for this to get fixed before you commit.

[h2]Preamble[/h2]

I've waited what felt like ages to play this game from the original awakening trailer in 2020, and learning that then CBUIII (Now known as Creative Studio III) helmed the project had me excited. I knew it would eventually make its way to PC so I patiently bided my time despite its PS exclusive status to start. And now roughly 4 years later all that waiting paid off. Luckily I was able to dodge about 90 percent of spoilers beyond what was shown in the pre-launch trailers and maybe 3 out of context screenshots I saw, and thank god. All I knew is that generally critic reception was good, and sort of like with every new FF game the fanbase was semi-divided. Maybe in part due to the gameplay or personal taste kinda stuff like the story, characters, or setting.

[h2]Game Review/Thoughts[/h2]

16 is not a perfect game, and I understand why it might push certain people away if they have rigid guidelines on what makes a Final Fantasy game to them. But 16 is a Final Fantasy through and though, and is more than deserving of its mainline namesake. If you've played 14 before you'll immediately notice the visual and story motifs used here. It feels like a nice showcase of what CBUIII is capable of with a big budget and collective vision for a single player narrative.

The things it gets right 16 does extremely well. Emotionally wrought Shakespearian-esque storytelling that takes you on a rollercoaster ride. Valisthea while picturesque is an unforgiving world where cruelty knows no bounds. But in the various tragedies and hardships does the 16 writing team showcase the indomitable human spirit, and the will to keep going in the face of adversity. In many ways it reminds me of the best parts of the Hydaelyn/Zodiark saga of 14 encapsulated in single player form by Maehiro, and not just Heavensward. The sidequest stories were also nice besides the given rewards they help immensely with world building, and giving more background to Valisthea's people (Take the time in your own leisure to do these if you haven't, they've made me become more attached to this "universe" by doing them). Also Clive is a wonderful leading protagonist whose POV we view the world, and while there's a generally amazing supporting cast you need to know everything in the game is in support of his story. A bold choice, but the right one I believe. 

The combat is fast and frenetic with a lot of room for skill expression for those that seek it despite how basic it might seem. It took me a bit to find a rhythm, but after getting 3 Eikon slots the potential really opens up. Not quite on the level of an actual character action game like DMC/Bayonetta, but enough where dedicated players can do some crazy combos while not taking any damage/parrying their way through battle. To me gameplay wise its a happy medium between "soulslike" combat, dynasty warrriors, and a platinum game in one. However for those not good at these types of games playing on story focused mode and using the timely accessories will allow you to get through the game with ease. I played on action focused mode and felt it was fair difficulty. Only 2 bosses towards the end game me a bit of trouble.

The OST showcases Soken's best work to date, and is another reminder to why he's so beloved for those who've experienced his previous arrangements in context. The various themes for the game are beautiful alongside their leitmotifs used in certain situations as well. I especially enjoyed the choral aspects which give certain tracks this either sobering or epic feel. The Titan themes have no business going that hard btw, you'll know what I mean when you get there if you play this lol. Also [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CeqyEzK87z4]"Find the Flame" (Clive's Theme)[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yf3wH29UYi8]"Away" (Joshua's Theme)[/url], and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RlRZi-War2o]"Winter's Bound/My Star" (Jill's Theme)[/url] are all amazing songs with breathtaking leitmotifs. Nobuo Uematsu will forever be FF's Beethoven and the GOAT, but Soken when he's given the opportunity is like Mozart. Both very different composers on the way they go about things, but should both be respected in their own right.

Lastly before I get to my critiques I'll get to art direction/visuals. While not every texture is rendered/created equal on the whole XVI is a very striking looking game, and really captures that dark western style fantasy look. It feels like Kazuya Takahashi's (Whom I often get confused with Akihiko Yoshida since their art is similar and they have a bit of crossover) impressionism is brought to life. The character designs particularly with the male character's hair is definitely FF lol, but the costumes/clothing seem fitting for the setting of the game. I've also grown to really like the way Clive looks as our protagonist over time. Just all in all great stuff. Different from the more easily recognizable known art work of Tetsuya Nomura, but in a good way. Not everything in Square Enix needs to be designed by that dude as beloved as he is.

[h2]Critiques/Complaints[/h2]

The pacing can at times be iffy, I've read/heard people have this as a major complaint. But I think its overblown and is not as bad as you think. That said I admit parts of the story do feel like it meanders a bit too much, and if you decide to do all the side quests as I in the base game you will feel this in particular. I think the devs could have added an additional difficulty mode on first playthrough that is a bit harder than action focused mode, but maybe not as crazy as Final Fantasy Mode (An additional new game+ difficulty) for those that wanted a more demanding challenge. And without spoilers I felt like the potential for some characters weren't realized with the amount of screen time they got. Gearing/Crafting in this game is pretty basic, like it exists, but is more a means to an end which is a bit of a missed opportunity. Same could be said of what you do in sidequests aside from additional story (Which was good). The world of Valisthea aside from the major interest points was not as exciting to explore unfortunately compared to other FF games. These issues all together prevent me from saying it's a 10/10 masterpiece or anything of that nature. Performance wise this also needs some work, it's playable but SE needs an optimization patch or two. I'm not even sure if I'm CPU or GPU bound at all. Or if it's a denuvo or a .exe priority thing since the microstutters when they happen are bad.

[h2]Conlusion[/h2]

This is the most fun and enjoyment I've gotten from a mainline game in what feels like forever. I think this might be a top-3 FF game for me despite its issues, the whole of 16 was greater than the sum of its parts. The team had a strong vision for what they wanted to make and stuck to it. I highly respect that, and CBUII's strengths are on full display here for all to see as are their weaknesses/limitations. I think everyone should give this a try when they get the chance. Even if you have to wait for it to go on sale. I've yet to dive into the DLC stories, but I will soon and will do separate reviews on them. I clocked in about 57 hours MSQ, clearing the hunt board, and doing all available sidequests. Expect a roughly similar playtime depending on the pace of your play. Did not touch the combat oriented challenge stuff like trials, but maybe one day.

[h1][b]Sidenote:[/b][/h1] The FPS is all over the place and this needs some performance optimization patches, I hope SE will do it. Otherwise I recommend these mods to help out with framerate issues and whatnot.

Thank you based [url=https://github.com/Lyall/FFXVIFix][b]Lyall[/b][/url] for FOV changes/other not included QoL, and then use this [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/finalfantasy16/mods/4][b]reg edit[/b][/url] when playing to help stabilize fps and then revert to default when not playing if you're having really bad microstutters like I was.

The game's cut-scenes are Quality, high details and cool eidolons in the frame. 
This Final Fantasy is a more linear one which is not bad after we had 15 as an open world and XIII kinda open world with sometimes linear parts. 
The story is also interesting and the combat is so good, I love that they asked the combat designer of Devil May Cry to help in this game and it shows. 
No cluster f*ck of a combat like in 15 and the combat feels very fun getting to LIMIT BREAK faster with dodging and abilities.

The only bad point in my eyes in NVIDIA ruining this game for people with even one gen older than their 40 series. 

A ryzen 7 5800 X3D and a 3080 with 32 Gb RAM in the hands of an IT should be sufficient to run this game, even 15 looked better than this now, but why would you ask?
Ngreedia nerfing the 30 series with "not being able to run''  frame generation, trust me it can do that they just sold too few so they want us to upgrade. 
The card wasn't even using 100 percent of the core die, I got stuck at 85% usage on my 3080 at 1440p. I got a 320 bit bus which 40 series got nerfed in and still got locked software wise.

So I fiddled with some settings and came to the conclusion that 1:
-Nvidia will not be my next brand for a GFX card 
2:
-AMD had to f*cking help me get more frames. 

If you have some trouble with a 3080 try this trick:
Put FSR3 on, put upscaling to Quality and AMD FSR Frame generation on and you will see a big increase, yes on a 3080 we need to use AMD software, Nvidia just nerfed us software wise. 

Then close the game and do this:

Go to %AppData% with the win+R then go back to Local and then to SquareEnix FINAL FANTASY XVI and fully delete the file called "ffxvi_b96bc3fb.psol" Start the game again, and enjoy the frames Ngreedia stole from you,

Cheers!

Instead of reusing popular formulas,  FFXVI builds their hack & slash based on their popular RPG assets (iconic bosses, summons, magic, and skills). I think that's why the action parts left me with a better impression than I expected.
For example:
1. The iconic FF elements are well-integrated and balanced.    
2. Don't have to wait for an obvious 'turn' after my opponent spam combos after combos. Opening comes fairly often, and worth a player to maximize their combo to fight back.  
3. The protagonist won't get stagger/flinch like a soccer player. 
4. Move sets are clean, flexible, and interact well with enemies. Players have much room to be creative, at least not to the extent of 'everyone beats the boss similarly'.
5. Enemies won't abuse winding, delays, and input reading. Just fair and challenging.
Maybe I am just so tired of the trending elements these days... but I am sincerely having fun because FF brings out its own flavor successfully.

Many of the core mechanics are simply very fun to do - farming, fishing, combat, even cooking. I loved getting to experiment with different builds, and experiment with different recipes to make buffs to complement those builds. Bosses are decently fun, but the progression as a whole is really where the game shines. I was really excited to see just what I could fish up when I got to a new area, or what items the enemies dropped.

I heard about Core Keeper during the official release sale and picked it up. I am so glad that I did. It has been a long time since I have found a game that has pulled me in like this one has. The game play loop of exploration, looting, base building, and all the other systems and mechanics is quite satisfying. I love the fact that there is no hand holding and no pressure to accomplish objectives other than the allure to explore and experiment. 

At present I have been enjoying hopping worlds with my main character and setting up resource harvesting for my main world. I have just discovered automation and the order that can bring. I have since bought a copy for each of my children and we are all playing on a dedicated server I am hosting in my home. It has become one of our favorite pass times now.

The only gripe I have, and it is minor, is inventory management. I think like many this can be done better. Primarily a way of dealing with seeds and decorative plants. It would also be nice to have a larger radius for pulling resources from chests when crafting.

Core Keeper is a great game. I am already 66 hours in and it has flown by. I can see myself playing this game for hundreds of hours and not getting bored.

10/10 sandbox game

Definitely really tried to like this game. The art and music is amazing, but the game is EXTREMELY grindy. 

The game definitely feels like it doesn't respect your time with a fairly large map that takes awhile to move around in. Making things such as a minecart network feels like a hassle, since mine carts  / boats aren't equipped to your character, but placed on the rail network, so if you die, you'll have to walk all the way back to get your vehicle.  Fast travel points are few and far between, and the only way (As far as I know) to create an additional fast travel point is extremely resource intensive and has a TEN minute cooldown.

You'll also need a large amount of materials for a lot of stuff in the game, which the game seems to flirt with automating the process a bit by having automated drills to get these resources for you.  The way you can automate things is extremely basic however, and will require you to just randomly explore until you find an appropriate node you can place your drills at. 

The gearing for combat in this game also feels pretty basic, and doesn't have as much synergies as I'd like. For example, I equipped an armour set that increases crit chance upon poisoning an enemy. However I found that this trait doesn't proc when using a range weapon that poisons enemies, when using a character skill that inflicts poison whenever you deal damage, or when using a pet that poisons enemies. It seems to only proc when using a poison melee weapon - which wasn't mentioned in the description of the armour set. 

The breaking point for me in this game was [spoiler] A large underwater sea section, which you basically need a boat for traveling around at. There's a water boss in this section without a fast travel point near it. Dying to it not only means having to make the long trek back, but you'll either need to remake your really expensive boat or make a long land bridge back to your stuff[/spoiler]

Ultimately, I was looking for something to scratch my survival crafting itch, but there's not enough here to justify the massive grind.

I have never been into 2d games, I have never been into civ building, I have never been into indie games. 

And I love this! Time flies when you are playing this.

I did a full play through with a friend in a single seed to 100% the game in a little over 120 hours.  The progression of this game is fantastic and the crafting system is easy to use/follow.  Go-karts, Boating, PvE, PVP, boss battles... I was never bored playing this game as there is always something to do.  The customization you are allowed to make in game is endless (painting, flooring, walls, farming, automation, mob spawning, etc.).  Essentially you need to defeat certain bosses to gather parts to power the core, which will unlock more of the available map.  There are also optional bosses, ALL of which have fun mechanics and I recommend trying all boss fights.  The appearance of the game to me was appealing, giving almost a retro feel to the game.  This game felt like it took great aspects from other games I've played and put it into one. 
 Very fun game, definitely recommend it.  

Things I've learned/tips:
1.)  Using the Map - to place the Icons, select the desired icon and click the middle mouse button on the map to add; click on same spot to remove.  Mark boss fighting/summoning locations to find easier later on.
2.)  If you want to customize flooring that doesn't allow it to be painted; put a "glass floor" on top of it, then paint it.  May find a color you like w/ that pattern.
3.)  Create Scanners to find bosses, sooo much more convenient than blindly running around the map.
4.)  Save the figurines you collect.  There's a way to "power" them to have them spawn that type of mob; they do not drop loot, though still grant exp for your skill ups.
5.)  You have 3 different gear sets, recommend binding those sets to hotkeys.  Some fights may be much easier if/when you switch armor sets/tactics during the fight.

Hope the above helps, enjoy!

The game has been super fun. Started with hard mode and it provided enough of a challenge to keep the game interesting. The game provides enough variety of activities to keep you exploring without tiring out from any one activity. When you get tired of fishing, for example, you move on to something else for a while. 

I'm not a min/max kind of player, so I do my own builds with whatever I find via natural play through and was able to find some of the legendary weapons in good time. Ranged weapons are very good in this game, especially physical ranged like the daggers. Overall, Armor sets favor physical melee and ranged builds. There are some for casters or summoners as well, but they aren't very strong end game and fall off fast. Mainly because there are only two books to summon creatures. At some point  the mana cost gets to be too high and the bats are too dumb for combat situations to really focus on summons and I found myself using daggers or other weapons like the fireball staff to compensate. I really really tried making a summoner build work on its own, but I couldn't get through some of the content even though I was geared fairly well. Switched to physical range and beat everything no problem. At the time of me writing this, I have only the remaining two titans left, which I'm about to tackle next. 

Good game and definitely worth playing. Can't wait to see what else they'll add. Hoping that summoners get some more love

40 hrs so far and for the most part, Ive really had a good time. I do feel like the game suffers from an identity crisis. Does it want to be an open world survival like Minecraft, something casual like Stardew Valley, or more of a Boss a Rush type of game?

The postive thing ia that you get a little bit of all 3, but the negative is that you have to deal with game mechanics that intentionally slow you down.

Example, Trying to farm Wool, but you can only do it every 10 real time minutes. Bosses that have a cooldown before they respawn. Or farming for the 3 upgrade materials, Emearld,Ruby, and Sapphire which take forever without a Mob spawner. 

If you can look past the obnoxious grind for materials, I think youll enjoy your stay here. Alot of these materials arent necessary until later in the game depending on how fast you push into the next zone.


Boss are cool. Lots of sets and diversities. The upgrade station allows all early gear to stay relevant if one choose to upgrade them. 

Looking forward to future updates. Hoping they remove uncessary bottlenecking or change them in a way that is less annoying. 

Example, Cattle should give the materials right away, Then go on a cooldown. Instead of feeding them, waiting 10 mintues then getting the item.

If you’ve ever wondered what it would be like to survive in a world overrun by zombies, Project Zomboid is the game for you. With a heavy focus on realism and player choice, this survival sandbox offers a deeply immersive experience that few other games can match. Whether you’re managing your character’s health, building your dream base, or evading hordes of undead, Project Zomboid keeps you on your toes at every moment. Having spent over 730 hours in the game, I can confidently say that it delivers one of the best survival experiences available today.

1. Realism Done Right
Despite the fictional backdrop of a zombie apocalypse, Project Zomboid nails realism in almost every aspect of gameplay. The most valuable tip for any new player is simply: "What would you do in this situation?" The game's health system is intricate, with injuries, illnesses, and mental states all playing a role. Clothes protect you from zombie bites, degrade over time, and help regulate body temperature, which is vital. Mechanics like repairing vehicles, dealing with character traits and professions, and managing inventory weight make everything feel real. I especially love how character emotions and moods affect gameplay – it’s small touches like these that elevate Project Zomboid to another level of immersion.

2. An Open World That Never Ends
The current game world is massive, and despite having played over 730 hours, I still didn't explore all the areas. I admire the sheer size of the map, and with upcoming updates promising to expand it further and even include randomly generated maps in the distant future. Project Zomboid also offers infinite gameplay and replayability. It’s one of those survival games you can play over and over without ever getting tired.

3. Sandbox Customization Options
One of my favorite aspects is the ability to tailor the world to your liking. From the number and behavior of zombies to loot distribution, characters (players), and more, Project Zomboid lets you tweak almost anything. It gives you the power to create a world that fits your personal playstyle or challenge yourself with tougher scenarios.

4. Character Creation and Professions
This is hands-down one of my favorite features in the game. Choosing different professions and character traits, both positive and negative, significantly changes how the game plays. I also appreciate the subtle bonuses and drawbacks that aren’t immediately obvious – it adds an extra layer of depth. The balance in this system is present, too, so don’t expect to create an overpowered character unless you tweak the sandbox settings to do so!

5. Community Mods
While Project Zomboid doesn’t need mods to be great, the fact that they’re available is a huge bonus. The modding community has added incredible content, from enhanced realism to new vehicles, traits, weapons, and crafting options. There’s too much to describe in one review! That said, I recommend playing without mods at first to truly grasp the game’s mechanics, but later on, mods can make the experience even better.

6. Skill Levels and Physical Attributes
Project Zomboid features an extensive skill system that allows players to improve their characters through practice and experience. Skills are divided into categories like combat, crafting, survival, and agility, each having a noticeable impact on gameplay. Combat skills such as aiming and reloading become crucial for firearm users, while melee skills like blunt and blade proficiency determine how effective you are with weapons like baseball bats or axes. Crafting skills, including carpentry, metalworking, and tailoring, let you fortify your base, repair clothes, or even create tools from scratch.
Survival skills like foraging and fishing allow you to live off the land when resources run dry, and farming lets you grow your own food, providing a sustainable source of nutrition. Agility skills, such as sneaking and lightfooted, are essential for staying hidden from zombies, while sprinting helps you escape when the situation gets dire.
Physical attributes like strength and fitness are equally important, as they directly affect how much weight you can carry, how fast you tire, and how effective you are in combat. Improving your strength means you can carry heavier loads and hit harder with melee attacks, while better fitness ensures you can run longer distances and recover faster from exhaustion. Each skill progresses the more you use it, making every action in the game feel meaningful and rewarding.

7. Intriguing (But Optional) Lore
While the storyline isn’t central to the player’s experience yet, it does exist, and it’s fascinating. I only started diving into the game’s lore after playing for about 500 hours, and once I did, I was hooked. I went so far as to read up on the game’s backstory online (beware of spoilers!) Exploring the lore adds a new dimension to the game. I highly recommend getting to know the lore yourself!

8. A Sandbox Experience
Want to build? Build. Want to destroy? Go ahead. In Project Zomboid, your creativity (and characters human possibilities) are your only limits. The only challenge is gathering materials, which makes sense given the post-apocalyptic setting. But with enough time and motivation, you can accomplish incredible things. This open-ended approach is perfect for players who enjoy creating and building their own worlds.

9. Active Developer Support
The game is still in early access, and while it may not be updated on a daily basis, the developers deliver large, meaningful updates. They listen to player feedback, fix bugs, and continue to improve the game without ignoring the community, which is something I greatly respect.

10. Hidden Depths
Just when you think you’ve learned everything there is to know about Project Zomboid, it surprises you. The game is full of hidden mechanics and features that add to the depth of the experience. I’ve had several moments where I thought I had mastered the game, only to discover a new layer of complexity. It’s a game that keeps on giving.

11. Fair Price
Finally, let’s talk about the price. For what Project Zomboid offers, the price is perfect. But if you’re looking to save a bit of money, it’s always worth waiting for a sale. Either way, you’re getting your money’s worth for this gem of a game.

Project Zomboid is a truly exceptional survival game that combines deep realism with sandbox freedom. Whether you're fighting off zombies, building your own fortress, or scavenging for supplies, every moment feels impactful. With continuous updates, an active modding community, and endless replayability, it’s a game that will keep you coming back for more. I can’t recommend it highly enough to fans of survival games or anyone looking for a challenging, immersive experience.

Many of the core mechanics are simply very fun to do - farming, fishing, combat, even cooking. I loved getting to experiment with different builds, and experiment with different recipes to make buffs to complement those builds. Bosses are decently fun, but the progression as a whole is really where the game shines. I was really excited to see just what I could fish up when I got to a new area, or what items the enemies dropped.

I heard about Core Keeper during the official release sale and picked it up. I am so glad that I did. It has been a long time since I have found a game that has pulled me in like this one has. The game play loop of exploration, looting, base building, and all the other systems and mechanics is quite satisfying. I love the fact that there is no hand holding and no pressure to accomplish objectives other than the allure to explore and experiment. 

At present I have been enjoying hopping worlds with my main character and setting up resource harvesting for my main world. I have just discovered automation and the order that can bring. I have since bought a copy for each of my children and we are all playing on a dedicated server I am hosting in my home. It has become one of our favorite pass times now.

The only gripe I have, and it is minor, is inventory management. I think like many this can be done better. Primarily a way of dealing with seeds and decorative plants. It would also be nice to have a larger radius for pulling resources from chests when crafting.

Core Keeper is a great game. I am already 66 hours in and it has flown by. I can see myself playing this game for hundreds of hours and not getting bored.

10/10 sandbox game

Definitely really tried to like this game. The art and music is amazing, but the game is EXTREMELY grindy. 

The game definitely feels like it doesn't respect your time with a fairly large map that takes awhile to move around in. Making things such as a minecart network feels like a hassle, since mine carts  / boats aren't equipped to your character, but placed on the rail network, so if you die, you'll have to walk all the way back to get your vehicle.  Fast travel points are few and far between, and the only way (As far as I know) to create an additional fast travel point is extremely resource intensive and has a TEN minute cooldown.

You'll also need a large amount of materials for a lot of stuff in the game, which the game seems to flirt with automating the process a bit by having automated drills to get these resources for you.  The way you can automate things is extremely basic however, and will require you to just randomly explore until you find an appropriate node you can place your drills at. 

The gearing for combat in this game also feels pretty basic, and doesn't have as much synergies as I'd like. For example, I equipped an armour set that increases crit chance upon poisoning an enemy. However I found that this trait doesn't proc when using a range weapon that poisons enemies, when using a character skill that inflicts poison whenever you deal damage, or when using a pet that poisons enemies. It seems to only proc when using a poison melee weapon - which wasn't mentioned in the description of the armour set. 

The breaking point for me in this game was [spoiler] A large underwater sea section, which you basically need a boat for traveling around at. There's a water boss in this section without a fast travel point near it. Dying to it not only means having to make the long trek back, but you'll either need to remake your really expensive boat or make a long land bridge back to your stuff[/spoiler]

Ultimately, I was looking for something to scratch my survival crafting itch, but there's not enough here to justify the massive grind.

I went in expecting something similar to Katana Zero, but it's so much more than that. Saying Sanabi is a Katana Zero clone would be a huge disservice to this game. To me, both are exceptional gems.

But before I continue to sing my praises to this game, what exactly is Sanabi?

Well, in this action platformer game, you play as a retired veteran with a simple mission, which is to hunt an entity called "Sanabi". To do this, you will use your chain hook prosthetic arm to get around a city called Mago. This weapon can also be used to hook yourself to the enemies, destroying them in the process.

This grappling hook mechanism means that you will spend most of your time in the air, going from one platform to another, from one enemy to another, from one boss to another. And when done right, it feels oh so good, especially because of the tight movement. Makes you feel unstoppable, and it gets the adrenaline pumping!

I said "when done right", because at first, I struggled getting used to the grappling hook gameplay and gamepad controls. Because not only you can hook the enemy, you can boost yourself, slow down time, jump, and so much more. But overtime, I learned to get good and finally experienced that flow state.

Surprisingly, even with this addicting gameplay formula, my favorite part of Sanabi is still the story. Without spoiling anything, you will be confused at first because of the mysteries surrounding Sanabi and Mago are pretty complicated, but once you connect the dots, it will be mind blowing. 

At least mine did, that's for sure. It makes me want to replay the whole game instantly to see all the hints I missed.

Not only mind blowing, Sanabi's story has a lot of heart thanks to its characters. Mind you, Sanabi doesn't have too many characters, since you spend most of your time with a hacker girl named Mari, who's helping you find Sanabi, and her robot companion Mufin.

While Mari might be too talkative to some, I found her character very charming, I really enjoyed her funny personality and antics, and I think the game definitely won't be the same without Mari.

I was too invested in the story of Sanabi, the retired veteran, and Mari. By the end of the game, I was left sobbing my eyes out, heck, I instantly went to write a review, three years after I wrote my previous review.

All of these positive points, combined with the epic soundtracks and the eye catching pixel art, makes the game a complete package worth checking out, even in full price. Scratch that, I insist YOU to try out this game if you love some fast paced action gameplay and heart tugging storytelling.

With that being said, to Wonder Potion a.k.a the developers, I'll be looking forward to your future games! Doesn't matter if it will start as an Early Access product again, I WILL be there!

The game is good, and it's easy to recommend for the price, but it does have an off-putting issue.

The story, the artstyle, the game mechanics, the world-building, and the soundtrack are all top notch. It does however get really tedious at times. It's clearly heavily inspired by Katana Zero, but where Katana Zero effortlessly succeeds in integrating an intriguing plotline with its fast-paced gameplay. This one fails; miserably at times. It felt like the cutscenes and gameplay were constantly interrupting each other, the second you get into the gameplay and are being thrown challenging enemies, you're interrupted by a cutscene twice as long, and when the story gets interesting, you're interrupted with the gameplay. At some point it was hard to enjoy the game cause there was this constant anticipation that the gameplay would come to a grinding halt with a dense cutscene.
I played the speedrun after completing the campaign, and playing it felt leagues better than story mode, the gameplay felt more connected and fluid.
The story is definitely worth experiencing but I don't think it warrants the awful gameplay to cutscene ratio. A lot of it could have been condensed, some of it could have been shown in collectables or records people who are interested could go out of their way to find, having cutscenes between longer sequences of gameplay, etc.

It's good but it would've felt so much better had it put its fast-paced gameplay front and centre, and it seems they could've easily done that.
Has difficulty spikes at times, but worth seeing it to the end.

I have to give this a very reluctant thumbs up.  This is a very good game, but it is certainly not a game that deserves an "Overwhelmingly Positive" tag.  Here's why:

(1) The best part of this game is the story; there is little doubt about that. Though the story is very good, it is absolutely not original, as it is basically an exact copy of a couple very specific movies. Still, the story is worth getting through. I suggest you don't read anything about it and just go through it without any spoilers of any type, even the trailers.

(2) The problem with this "game" is that there is too much emphasis on the story.  You will spend significantly more time watching cut scenes and reading dialogue than actually playing.  That sounds like an exaggeration, but it is 100% true. There is LESS TIME SPENT ON GAMEPLAY THAN ON CUT SCENES. 

(3) The game took some obvious inspiration from Bionic Commando.  Swinging around is fun, but that is basically all you do.  There is little combat here and it is as simplistic as you can possibly get while still calling this a game. 

(4) It way too easy. The challenge of the game is figuring out and becoming adept with the controls.  Once you do that, you fly through the game with ease. 

Some of the reviews compare this to Katana Zero, even saying that it is better than Katana Zero.  I don't think this game is playing in the same league as Katana Zero.  Katana Zero is a far superior game. 

This could have been a legitimate classic if there was more time spent on gameplay and less on cut scenes. This game is a B.  I am not suggesting that you should not play it, as it has its fun parts, but this is really more a movie than a video game.

I'd say this game is great if you just focus on the main parts of the game and just enjoy your time with what you have.
However, if you want to play stuff that isn't included stock... well, your wallet definitely won't be thanking you any time soon.

The music is pretty good, I'd say for every, "Meh, it's okay," you'll have two, "Dang, that's pretty good." But to get that "WOW" feeling, you better cough up some of your precious dollars. This is because the songs that come with the game seem almost specifically designed to be a level or two below the paid content; not enough to really upset you, but just enough to sort of bug you. This will inevitably lead to you buying at least one of the DLC that you simply don't need. All of that knocks off a good chunk of the out-of-ten score.

If you're okay with spending money on what is, admittedly, a decent variety of songs (even if it's an objectively bad deal), then you'll have a really good experience. It's not just the songs that are better; the mapping is, too. The maps in the base-game are alright, but most of them lack a certain level of enjoyment. The DLC maps fix that, in my opinion, bringing the count of really good or enjoyable maps from 1 in 5 to 1 in 3 (or even 1 in 2). The DLC is definitely high quality from what I've seen.

But don't fret over that high price-tag as I once did. There are plenty of sales throughout each year to really enable your addiction to spending, with packs plummeting from around $30 (CAD) to just $7; sometimes, the prices can get even lower than that, so keep an eye out.

Hope this review helped someone. Thanks for reading :)

[b]DJMAX RESPECT V[/b] is one of the most well-crafted rhythm games I’ve ever played. Every penny spent on it is worth the experience. One of the first things that impressed me was how unique and distinct each theme is, with every theme having its own background music when selecting modes. Each chart has its own music video, and if it doesn’t, the game creates an original one, clearly showing the level of care and investment from the developers.

The game is frequently updated, not only adding new songs but also introducing more difficulty levels to older charts. The game features four modes: 4B, 5B, 6B, and 8B. If you want to "get good," you should play every mode, starting from 4B, then progressing to 6B, and so on.

In terms of value, if you're lucky enough to buy the game and its DLCs during a sale, it’s a steal. I was able to get the full game at 80% off.

My only minor complaint is that the game doesn’t have many collaborations with other major rhythm games. While Chunithm and Muse Dash are included, I’d love to see DJMAX RESPECT V collaborate with games like maimai or SDVX and feature more Japanese artists. However, I have to admit that the game already offers a diverse range of music for everyone. I’m not a big fan of K-pop, but DJMAX changed my mind. I got to know more lesser-known Korean artists like TAK, KATOMORI, and XeoN, and I must say, I’m really addicted to their music.

DJMAX RESPECT V truly offers an arcade-like experience at home. [b]Solid 10/10[/b].
