My favorite game right now. Better than Risk of Rain 2 and Skul quite possibly will stay my favorite roguelite for a very long time.

Very easy to run on devices, very snappy and intuitive movement, reminds me of cuphead.

Most games like this feel too easy and I end up limiting myself to make it harder. This game, however, is challenging. Each enemy has a different way you need to approach them and level design fits them well. 

Finally, what makes this game so replayable is: 
    -each item can be used in different builds in different ways making you think about item synergy
    -heads in this game can be upgraded a surprising number of times, meaning the developers made walk cycles, unique abilities, and tons and tons of sprites that make each and every different skull and rarity of skull unique
    -when you upgrade your skull there is never a painful change in playstyle. Upgrades always compliment your already developed style of fighting


110/100 definitely recommend

Really good Rogue-like! The skull mechanic is fun and even if some skulls are not as fun, those that are fun make this game really enjoyable. The story is fresh and interesting which is rare in rogue likes. Good difficulty, and when you think you are overpowered, the game is good at skillchecking you.

Skul the protagonist of the game is a pawn with an endless possibilities and builds. 
This is like Terraria where you pick your class at the start (in a manner of choosing a head lol), pick your item with stats (after finishing one room), upgrade your health and damage (earning black crystals after a one whole run).

The game is not restricting you on how you want to play it, like you can go full physical damage with crit + DoT wound debuff, or magic damage with freeze/stun debuff that lets you crowd control mobs and even bosses. I found myself trying so many different ways of playing the game. A standard run of Skul would atleast be around 30 to 45 minutes (not sure if you can reach the latest boss in that time), still depends with your build and also SKILLS. 

This game is amazing, and I highly recommend you to play this.

Probably my most played roguelike ever. I won't say it's entirely balanced in it's mechanics (revenge is op and is practically necessary to beat the harder difficulties/some skulls just feel objectively better than others), but the way the system mechanics work with eachother and the feeling of empowerment once you find a build that hits is a dopamine rush that always hits. This is also a skill based platformer "hack and slash" i guess you could call it, where your skill is just as important as your build and the feeling of improvement learning how to dodge enemy attack patterns is very satisfying. 

A standard run of skul from start to finish will run you about 40 minutes (it saves every room so you can quit and come back whenever). It has a sort of maplestory vibe once you get later into the run, bigger damage numbers and crushing waves of enemies with singular spells, while still having it feel really meaty as you do just from the effort you spent getting to that point. The boss fights are also extremely challenging and it feels good to finally kill one after being stuck on it. I would say this game lands on the harder end of 2D platformers, you really need to master the mechanics to beat the end game bosses. 

Having beaten the hardest difficulty possible and pretty much exhausting all of the content of the game, I got a good 120 hours out of it. Good game. DLC is pretty nice too, just a gives more options for skull/items per run and a new final boss.

Honestly just one of the best games I have ever played. Every single skull feels unique (even if I dislike a few of them) and both the story and world are wonderfully written. If I only had to play one roguelite for the rest of my life, this game would easily be among my top 3 options.

Skul: The Hero Slayer is an entertaining but very challenging roguelike. The game is fairly short, but trying out all the different skulls, their evolutions and the abilities that come with them is fun and will keep you going for a while. Be warned, the game is very difficult! You could try to learn all the enemies' patterns but no matter what, you can be quickly overwhelmed by a horde of 20+ enemies. Instead, your best chance is to find a strong skull (e.g. the ghoul or the minotaurus) and create the perfect build (e.g. focus on physical damage). And if you're getting discouraged, you can always lower the difficulty of the game.

Skul: The Hero Slayer is a breath of fresh air in the roguelite genre, offering a unique twist on the traditional hero's journey. In this game, you play as Skul, a diminutive skeleton warrior fighting against the "heroes" who have invaded the Demon King's castle. The role reversal is both refreshing and entertaining.

The game's standout feature is its innovative skull-swapping mechanic. With over 90 different skulls to collect, each offering distinct playstyles and abilities, the gameplay remains fresh and engaging throughout multiple runs. This system encourages experimentation and adapts to various player preferences, whether you enjoy melee combat, ranged attacks, or magical abilities.

Visually, Skul is a treat. The pixel art style is charming and detailed, bringing the dark fantasy world to life with vibrant colors and fluid animations. The character designs are particularly noteworthy, with each skull transformation showcasing unique and often humorous personalities.

The combat is fast-paced and satisfying, with responsive controls that make navigating through hordes of enemies a joy. The difficulty curve is well-balanced, offering a challenge to seasoned players while remaining accessible to newcomers.

The roguelite elements are well-implemented, with each run feeling different thanks to the variety of skulls, items, and randomized level layouts. The permanent upgrade system provides a sense of progression that keeps you coming back for "just one more run."

While the story isn't the main focus, it offers enough intrigue to keep players invested, with some interesting lore tidbits scattered throughout the game.

One minor criticism is that some skull combinations can feel overpowered, potentially reducing the challenge for experienced players. However, this also allows for some incredibly fun and epic moments.

The Investigations Collection is a fantastic HD port of one solid game and one amazing game that together tells one of the best stories in the entire Ace Attorney series of games. The HD sprite artwork is fantastic, and sets a far better aesthetic standard for the series going forward than the ugly, made-for-handheld 3D models used in Dual Destines and Spirit of Justice. The collections run perfectly on both PC and Steamdeck and I've had no trouble with running them at my monitors native refresh rate and resolution (165hz/1440p). 

As for the games themselves, it's a bit more subjective but the takeaway I'd want to give is this; while the first Investigations game is only *good*, AAI2: Prosecutor's Gambit is a high point for the series not seen since the original trilogy and manages to tell a story that one could argue tops even the original game and Trials and Tribulations. If you are an Ace Attorney fan, it is truly unmissable. I'd say you could get through both games here in around 40 hours (I took my time). 

Really hope they continue down this path and expand on the Investigations format and the series as a whole.

Spending 62 hours to finish both AAI and AAI2, it is a really nice experience. Before playing AAI series, I have played all the other games of Ace Attorney series, and I am absolutely the fan of Ace Attorney. Because I love the rest of games of the series, once AAI can be pre-ordered, I purchased it with no hesitation.

For the game content, the new versions of chibi sprite are really really nice and delicate, which can definitely show the efforts of developer team. Meanwhile, the story and characters are also awesome, and Edgeworth is a better protagonist than Apollo and Athena from my point of view. I also like Shi-Long Lang very much, whose kindness towards his followers attracts me a lot. 

In general, I like AAI series more than Apollo trilogy and Great Ace Attorney series. The story of AAI2 is more interesting than AAI, but AAI is also a great game with lots of turnabouts. I highly recommend people who have finished and like Ace Attorney Phoenix Trilogy to play this investigation series, where you can find a lot of familiar faces, too.

To sum the rest of this review up, these two games are absolutely excellent titles in the Ace Attorney series and a must-play for anyone who enjoyed the other games. Both games mix up the Ace Attorney formula a bit by not actually occurring inside the courtroom (for the most part), but in turn spice up the investigation portion by giving you the ability to actually walk around the crime scene and make deductions yourself. These games are more fast paced than other mainline entries, and I don't ever recall being particularly stuck on any investigation section unlike what happens in a few cases of other Ace Attorney games. I definitely missed the courtroom sections from other games, but you still retain the gameplay of those for the most part, since you will often listen to testimony and issue rebuttals (essentially just cross-examination). Overall, the gameplay is both familiar enough to be fun for any Ace Attorney fan, but different feeling enough to stand out from the rest.

As for story, both games have excellent cases and characters, and I would rate many cases among the best in the entire series. I definitely must say that, in my opinion at least, the second game of the collection is by far stronger in terms of both overall story and character development. I won't spoil anything specific, but the second game spends a lot of time fleshing out Edgeworth as a character as he moves through the events of the game. I'm glad that Capcom released this collection, because before this the second game was never officially translated into English, which is a crying shame. I concede that I never played the fan translation, which I have heard is excellent, but I am nonetheless glad we finally have an official release of the game outside of Japan. 

This collection is absolutely worth playing for Ace Attorney fans both for more Ace Attorney kino in general, but also the great character development we see in classic characters like Edgeworth and Gumshoe. If nothing else in this review convinces you, please play these games so you can witness Gumshoe's finest hours.

A strong duology. With a great art style, colorful new characters, perfect reuse of old and recurring characters, and a good difficulty level - this collection does not disappoint. Easily in the top three ace attorney collections (original PW trilogy and TGAAC being the other two).

Each Edgeworth game could stand on its own, but both being bundled together helps them build off of each other in an enjoyable way. The first game sets up a fairly strong foundation for the second game. The second game uses callbacks and references to the first in a tasteful way.

If I had to nitpick, the second game's case #4 has disruptive pacing for its conclusion that ruins the immersion a tad. FWIW, case #5 cleans that up fairly fast - but it probably could've been handled better. Also, at least currently, there's a few glaring typos in the English localization in game #2 which ruin the immersion.

This is Must Play for any Phoenix Wright fan.   While this game focuses only Investigations and no court trials, its still classic Ace Attorney story and gameplay.  All the plot twists and turns you would expect, and lots of familiar characters if you are a Phoenix Wright fan. I played part 1 originally on the 3Ds back when it came out, but part 2 is brand new to the US.   Theres a lot of Miles Edgeworth background and backstory.  This is a great appetitizer until we can get a new Phoenix Wright game.

This is a remaster of a masterpiece. I haven't gotten to Prosecutor's Gambit yet, but the first one has been pretty good so far. The HD sprites and HD backgrounds are impressive, and the chibi sprites are really cute and smoother than your average animation. The UI is nice and user-friendly, and the remade sound and effects in the logic part are very cool. My favourite part of this game is being able to run around and explore, instead of being constrained to looking at one scene like in previous Ace Attorney games or Dual Destinies and Spirit of Justice. It just makes it more immersive, as you play the role of prosecutor/detective exploring the crime scene. Ambassador Alba is still the worst, as always, but in this game, when your health bar runs out, you can immediately load that scene again with full health instead of loading your previous save, which may have been from a long time ago. This saves you a lot of trouble having to save before every cross-examination. The gallery featuring concept art and music is chill and healing. It's not much, but it's great and interesting to visit once in a while. I highly recommend playing this if you have played it before when the graphics were all pixelated.

I have a strange relationship with the Ace Attorney series. On one hand, I do admire the original game and the rest of the two titles in the original trilogy have lots of wonderful moments as well. On the other – I’m not a fan of the ration between adventuring and visual novel storytelling they ever had, very heavily leaning into walls of text and sacrificing gameplay logic over plot twists. That’s the main reason why I stopped playing a couple of hours into The Great Ace Attorney Chronicles as it bored me to tears and I’ve never bothered with the second trilogy either. Which is why I wasn’t sure if I should give Ace Attorney Investigations Collection a go. But after playing the demo and discovering to my relief that this game, as the name implies, is far more into investigative adventuring than the other titles, I gave it a go. And I’m glad I did, as Ace Attorney Investigations: Miles Edgeworth is easily the most enjoyable entry in the series I’ve played. And it will probably be the last one I ever finish.

If you’re unfamiliar with Ace Attorney series, they are titles that combine light adventuring elements and visual novel-style storytelling to bring a rather unique experience of a court room drama. All the rest of the titles in the series are focused almost exclusively on said drama itself, with occasional investigative bits that are entirely linear and extremely primitive. So most of the time is spent on cross-examining someone’s testimonies in court and presenting correct evidence to highlight contradictions in them. Which, as I’ve mentioned already, involves way too much expository talking for my personal liking, as the games feel far more like barely interactive storybooks than adventure games. The original trilogy is still quite fun, especially the first game, but for all the fun twists and funny moments, the further the games went, the more they decided to sacrifice fun adventure elements in favor of guessing correct inputs to move plot forward, even if it’s not always logical. And the plot itself went from over the top and silly, to completely absurd and obnoxiously overcomplicated.

Ace Attorney Investigations breaks away from this approach. Instead of ditching the investigative part, the games (or, well, the first one at least) focuses a lot more on them, providing relatively simple, but genuinely engaging investigative gameplay where you examine the crime scenes, question the witnesses and suspects and connect clues. If you’ve played any of the titles that focus on the similar things, be it Sherlock Holmes titles, Detective Grimoire series or something like L.A. Noire, you know what to expect in general. It’s just somewhat simplified, without (at least usually) holding your hand and still providing the excitement from discovering hidden connections that may change your understanding of the case. Cross-examining testimonies is still present as well, but this time outside of the court setting and is used to bring out new information out of someone who intentionally or accidentally lied, or putting a criminal in a spot where they might reveal who they are to the surrounding crowd of witnesses, making the job of the police easier.

And given that the only game in the collection that I’ve completed is the first one (I’ll talk about the second when we get there),  I have to say that Ace Attorney Investigations: Miles Edgeworth is worth the purchase of the collection alone. It’s not without its flaws, for example the final case lasts way too long and becomes increasingly more absurd and convoluted as it goes. But even that one has strong moments and in general the flow of the game and its story is perfectly delivered. It makes sense, nothing feels too absurd to ruin the gameplay process, cases are interesting (even if they are way too reliant on murder) and vast majority of the logic checks are indeed logical and not of the “guess what the developer was thinking” kind. It’s better enjoyed if you do play the original trilogy of games first as some of the references and returning characters work much better with that knowledge. But it’s not like the original trilogy wasn’t worth playing on its own anyway, so you might as well do it. This isn’t Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective – that adventure game is beyond fantastic, while this one is just very very good. But it’s worth experiencing if you like investigation focused titles or like the Ace Attorney series.

Then I started playing Ace Attorney Investigations 2: Prosecutor’s Gambit and gave up in the middle of the second case. Apart from adding a horrendous new mechanic of “mind chess”, which might be the worst “dialogue battle”-type mini-game I’ve ever experienced in my life, this title just starts with the clown makeup half-applied, and rapidly continues to become a farce by the end of the first case. It’s incredibly stupid, throws several logic-defying “logic checks” at you from the get go, makes several characters that worked so well in the previous game unbearable and then somehow keeps getting even worse as it goes. It also seems to have almost entirely decided to ditch the focus of the investigation in favor of the mind-chess and testimonies, as while investigating still happens, it takes far less time then the talking bits. So after I realized that the game is actively irritating me and doesn’t plan on stopping, I quit it and doubt that I will ever return to finish it.

That said, as I’ve already mentioned, this collection could be not a collection but just Ace Attorney Investigations: Miles Edgeworth and I would’ve still said that it’s worth buying. Maybe not for the full price… but I honestly can’t say that it’s not worth that price, even if you would just play one of two games. It’s a shame that the series are, in general, not really my thing. And reactions from other people to the second game that I couldn’t stomach were quite positive from the fans of the franchise… So I guess, if you’re like me, just like a good adventure game and Ace Attorney never clicked with you before – the first game in the collection might be exactly what you’re looking for. Thankfully, you can try the demo to see for yourself if you want to get it. But I’m glad that I did.

Overall, a fun and entertaining experience to solve cases from Edgeworth's perspective. Definitely play at least games 1 and 2 of the original ace attorney trilogy first though if possible since certain character's character arcs will have already happened during those games, and so going back to them after playing these first might make those titles less enjoyable.

The good:
The characters are generally pretty lovable, with a lot of returning characters getting some form of new spin since they are interacting with Edgeworth instead of Wright. The second game alone makes the collection worth picking up. The first game gives some entertaining origin stories and is needed for context for the second game. The series also does a great job at making these entries feel like their own series and explores the characters appropriately - it stands alone incredibly well from a storytelling perspective even if many characters are reused from the original trilogy. However, definitely play at least the first two games of the original trilogy first to fully appreciate it.

The bad:
Game one is a bit slow and struggles with getting the new gameplay formula working well at times, such as where you'll figure something out and then someone shows up on the scene and requires you to explain the whole thing over to them when you just want to move on. If you can live without achievements, kind of wish I had just used story mode in game 1 for case 3 and the last half of case 5 since they drag way, way too much.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!

I didn’t expect to like this game. As an old-school Diablo 2 fan, I was skeptical, but with all the hype and seeing it on sale, I decided to give it a try. Somehow, the game sucks you in. It’s like watching grandma at the casino—every slot machine is hitting. Some of the payouts are pennies, and some are much bigger, but the idea that you might hit big or miss out on the next great item or event keeps you hooked.

There’s a lot of flash and bang, action-packed gore to keep things interesting, and plenty of ways to build your character. You can easily spend hours just sitting at your stash, or googling new ways to improve a single build. I wouldn’t say it’s the best game out there, but it definitely does the job when it comes to keeping you entertained.

I held off on buying this game for a long time because I do not want to support the idea of a battle pass.  I find they often ruin great games.  I eventually gave in and bought this during a trial period and really enjoyed it, so much so that I bought it, despite my grumblings against it.  Since then I've enjoyed it, despite the battle pass, which only has cosmetic rewards.  I still don't love the idea of a battle pass but the fact that the battle pass is purely cosmetic helps water it down for me.  Another thing that helps greatly is that the free tier of armor looks really amazing.  They didn't skimp on armor cosmetics to try and guide people towards buying cosmetics, which is a big plus and actually the only reason I would recommend the game.  As far as game play goes, it's been really fun.  End game is a little complicated and to get anywhere you have to follow someone else's build but that's pretty standard for RPGs these days.

Perfect for the steam deck as long as you have an internet connection. Easy time killer, fun to play and easy to learn. This is my first time playing with this IP and I am having a blast. I would recommend it for someone who likes a strategy game mixed with slaying monsters and creatures from a high 3rd person view style. The visuals are also quite good especially on the steam deck; which is what I buy a lot of games for since I travel a ton. Expansion coming in October as well to continue the story and add new game mechanics, characters and abilities. The only downside I have with this game is that it needs to be connected to the internet the entire time and you can not play offline.

Monkey King's Reign: The Global Impact of 'Black Myth: Wukong'
By KAI WOOD|Aug 26,2024
Chongqing - Black Myth: Wukong, a Chinese AAA game, has taken the gaming world by storm, smashing sales records and captivating millions of players with its breathtaking combat, stellar production quality, and unforgettable boss fights. Despite some skepticism from Western media outlets like IGN, the game has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from gamers around the globe. To explore what makes this game so special, Bridging News reached out to some Western gamers in China.

The New Evolution of Action RPG: 'Black Myth: Wukong'
Jacob Kapustinski, a dedicated gamer from Connecticut who is now living in Chongqing, China,  shared his thoughts on what makes this game stand out. 

Jacob's gaming journey began almost as soon as he could hold a controller. "I've been gaming my entire life," he recalls. "I was sitting on my dad’s lap, controller in hand, by the time I was three." His move to China seven years ago broadened his gaming interests. "Moving here, I've started appreciating different gaming styles, especially Chinese RPGs like Black Myth: Wukong." Jacob’s enthusiasm for the game is evident. "When the first trailer dropped five years ago, I was hooked. It was clear this game would be something special, and it hasn’t disappointed."


A Game That Lives Up to the Hype


Incredible cover art for the new AAA Game Black Myth: Wukong (Photo by Game Science)


"This game lives up to every bit of its hype," Jacob states. "It’s visually stunning, with tight controls and an engaging story. It's definitely China’s big entry into the AAA market." With about 30 hours of gameplay, Jacob is convinced of its impact. "It’s the new evolution of action RPGs, blending the best elements of Souls-like games with unique Chinese mythology. It’s a game that both challenges and immerses."

To get a sense of the local reaction, Huang HuiJing, a young man in Chongqing, thought of it as a hardcore Chinese gamer. "Every character has his own story, and it's a deeply Chinese story that is very meaningful to Chinese people. It's amazing. My friends and I, we all love it very much," he said before quickly returning to finish his boss fight. 

Showcasing Chongqing on a Global Stage


The UNESCO World Heritage Site Dazu Buddhist Sculptures are brought to the incredible and stunning fantasy world in Black Myth: WuKong (Photo by Game Science)


What sets Black Myth: Wukong apart is its deep cultural roots. Set against the backdrop of iconic Chinese locations like Chongqing’s Baoding Mountains and the Dazu Buddhist sculptures, the game weaves real-world beauty into its fantasy. "It’s fantasy, sure, but it’s so deeply rooted in real places that it makes you appreciate China’s culture and landscapes," Jacob explains. "This game is like a love letter to China. It’s going to make people around the world curious about these places, about Chongqing."

Igniting Conversations and Curiosity
Beyond its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Black Myth: Wukong is sparking deeper cultural conversations. James Mitchell, a Scottish teacher who lived in Chongqing before moving to the sunny beaches of Sanya, has noticed a shift in how people engage with Chinese mythology. "The game has spurred a lot of conversations about Chinese mythology," he observes. "My wife, who usually isn’t interested in gaming, is now fully engaged. She explains the mythical creatures and the rich lore behind them. It’s fascinating to see how the game brings these ancient stories to life, resonating with both Chinese and international audiences."

For James, Black Myth: Wukong's impact extends far beyond entertainment. "It’s a modern platform that not only entertains but also educates," he says. The game acts as an eye-opener for many players, offering a glimpse into history and mythology that they might not have explored otherwise."

James is eager to bring these discussions into his classroom. "I’m looking forward to encouraging students to explore and express their opinions on the game," he adds, "and to delve into the rich cultural heritage it portrays." This educational potential highlights Black Myth: Wukong's unique role in bridging cultural gaps and promoting a deeper understanding of Chinese mythology.

Facing Criticism Head-On


Asmongold, a top YouTube influencer known for his reactions and comments on new games, has heartily endorsed Black Myth: Wukong (Photo from Asmongold)


Despite its success, Black Myth: Wukong hasn’t escaped criticism, particularly from Western media. Jacob shrugs off the negativity. "Critics will always find something to nitpick, but the players love it. That’s what counts." YouTube personality Asmongold chimed in on the controversy, suggesting that the criticisms from outlets like IGN might stem from commercial motives rather than genuine concern. "They're more concerned with staying relevant than with what gamers actually want," Asmongold argues. "And gamers want Wukong."

A New Era for Chinese Gaming


Black Myth: Wukong, China's first AAA action-adventure game, has broken all records for single-player games already and shows no signs of slowing down (Photo from Game Science)

Jacob is excited about what Black Myth: Wukong means for the future. "China's mostly been known for mobile games, but this changes everything. Now, the world knows that China can produce big, high-quality, culturally rich games. This is just the beginning," he emphasizes. "This game shows that China is in the big leagues now, and it's only going to get better. We’re going to see more great games, a lot more like this, more China-made and Chinese culture games."

Black Myth: Wukong is more than a game; it's a cultural phenomenon, bridging gaps between East and West. As Jacob enthusiastically notes, "This isn't just about gaming—it's about sharing our stories, our culture, and showing the world what we can do."


Jorah Kai, the author of Kai's Diary, Amos the Amazing, and the soon-to-be-released A Sun Also Rises on Cthulhu, is both a big fan of action games and Chinese culture. Here, he stands on the Great Wall of China, protecting it against monsters and those who would blemish Sun Wukong's great legacy. (Photo by Jorah Kai)

I don't like the PSN thing as much as the next guy, but here's the thing: there's so many other more important things, such as climate change or women's reproductive rights, to get your panties in a twist about. The developer doesn't deserve the negative reviews the game is getting. If you have a social media account, then you're already getting taken advantage of way more than having to sign in to PSN to play this. Go put all this vitriol into something else that actually matters to the world and buy this game. Absolutely recommend at full price.

Reloaded game. Opened internet browser and verified stupid email for Sony. Tabbed over to the game and it wouldn't open. After maybe 20 seconds it crashed and Steam gave me a pop up error crash message. So sony PSN account nonsense crashed my game.

Reloaded game. Quite irritated at this point. I had to manually log in again to PSN. It asked me to verify account but I was able to click on "already verified" to get past that. FINALLY I thought... NOPE.

It asked me some annoying questions and terms and data crap but I saw a "do this later" button which I clicked on once again because this shouldn't matter I thought, I should be able to do this later in Settings or something. This ended the game again................................

I reloaded the game and guess what, had to manually log in AGAIN. So damn mad at this point.

I ignored the stupid "do this later" button which should've never existed in the first place because you literally cannot play if you click on it.

Finally got to the damn start screen. I went into settings and maxed everything out as usual. 4090/7950x3d/64gb. Game crashed in settings. I confirmed amd and nvidia drivers were up to date, which they were. Reloaded game.

Finally after like a half hour of bullshit I'm able to play. Thanks Sony! Negative review until the end of time from me.

In the future, any game requiring a PSN account from me will get a negative review even if the game blows my mind.

God of war Ragnarok is a rare type of sequel in the sense that its better than the first game in almost every way. The combat is much more refined to deliver a similar yet more polished experience than the 2018 game. The story itself is a very gripping and enthralling ride that I havent even finished yet despite me having almost 30 hours on the game and im just barely entering the final act. The side missions are very interesting and give some good lore about the areas you explore some of them even relating to characters Kratos and Atreus have encountered before, some of the rewards feel a bit lackluster at times but the game is typically pretty fair with the loot you get. Speaking of side content, there are a plethera of hidden bosses that i've encountered that if succeeding against them can easily get you a lot of xp and hacksilver, the boss fights are challenging yet fun that also feature a lot of different mechanics. Exploring more of the 9 realms is a journey in itself with each realm having a vibrant and unique look and feel, the graphics on this game are very good and sony delivered a very solid PC port so props to them. All in all id give this game a solid 9.5/10 so far, the only critique i could even have for it is that i wish the game was longer however, they were kind enough to make the free Valhalla DLC which is a roguelike experience in the post game that you can get a lot of time out of in itself.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. Cyberpunk isn't a good game by any measure and the less of its setting leaks into the real world, the better but if you do end up playing it, get Phantom Liberty and ignore the main game to the best of your ability.
The dlc is its own thing pretty much with an extra ending of its own, which has the added benefit of skipping the remainder of the core vidya.

Now, onto the good things: the script, the pacing, the dialogues, the execution of a properly polished thriller. The DLC adds some extra missions for old fixers. Fetch quests aside, the quest are good too, adding depth and nuance to the NPCs. Though the most important is the selection of end-game choices you're presented with. Between wetwork, dubious loyalties and complex motivations of dramatis personaes, someone did their homework on intelligence services so a lot of it offers a very authentic experience. A lot of times you leave feeling dirty - because that is the nature of the work. My only criticism is you couldn't off Meyers (it'd be tons of fun, I think), but otherwise it's next to excellent. Johnny's dialogue at the end of the lunar escape was a rare gem, diverging from his usual abrasive rants. Meeting Mr Hands in person was somewhat of a letdown, but more gigs from the sphinxian villain was welcome.

It's difficult to believe the DLC was produced by the same studio as the cliché and filth-filled dumpster fire that is the core game. The setting remains as disgusting as ever, with humanity locked in a dull and primitive state of neo-feudal corporate overlords or communes of plain-roaming barbarians, but Phantom Liberty redeems the price tag. If you find a way to skip to the DLC and just play the extra, do it: it is a real treat for any lovers of a spy drama - something Deux Ex tried and failed to do.

Edit: ending credits animation film was an outstanding tribute to the classic James Bond movies. Stellar.

Ah, “Phantom Liberty,” where the neon lights are brighter, the stakes are higher, and the glitches are… well, let’s just say they’re part of the charm. Imagine if James Bond, Keanu Reeves, and Idris Elba decided to throw a party in Night City, and you get to clean up the mess. That’s Phantom Liberty for you.

The expansion kicks off with the President of the New United States crash-landing in Dogtown. Yes, you read that right. Apparently, Air Force One now comes with a “crash here for plot development” button. You’re hired to rescue her, but not before you navigate through a maze of cybernetic baddies, morally ambiguous choices, and enough plot twists to make a pretzel jealous.

Idris Elba’s character, Solomon Reed, is the secret agent we all wish we could be. He’s suave, he’s mysterious, and he probably has a better skincare routine than you. Meanwhile, Keanu Reeves returns as Johnny Silverhand, still rocking that “I hate the system” vibe but with a touch more existential dread. It’s like watching your cool uncle go through a mid-life crisis, but with more explosions.

Dogtown itself is a marvel. It’s like someone took all the worst parts of a dystopian future and decided to make it a tourist attraction. The local wildlife includes cyber-enhanced gangsters and vending machines that might just try to sell you a grenade. But hey, at least the street food is to die for—literally.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment you’re making life-or-death decisions, the next you’re wondering why your character’s pants have suddenly disappeared. It’s all part of the Cyberpunk experience, folks. Embrace the chaos.

In conclusion, Phantom Liberty is the perfect blend of high-stakes drama, cybernetic mayhem, and unintentional comedy. It’s like a soap opera set in a dystopian future, and honestly, we wouldn’t have it any other way. So, grab your cyberdeck, put on your best trench coat, and dive into the madness. Just watch out for those vending machines.

Bro I'm playing this on a Strix GTX 960 w 12gb ram and 3ghz dual core from 12+ years ago and running this at 60fps via display port @ 1920x1080. Beyond well optimized. Its easily one of my favorite games to play right now.

Aside from running well, this game has been everything I wanted it to be and then some. Compared to the vibe of original FF7, I think this does it a lot of justice. The characters and dialogue are fun, the Shinra menace is equally pronounced etc.

The combat is so smooth I don't even know where to start. But somehow they made a turn-based FF game feel completely naturally FF in an action RPG environment. It's great.

The pacing is good, the side quests are cute and rewarding. I feel like I wasn't wasting much time if any in this game. Everything just sorta flows when you figure out the map.

I can praise this game all day. I'm on the last chapter as of today - I only have a few issues:

-The humor can be out of place sometimes along with the fan service. Particularly when you hear Tifa say 'Man I really need a shower' for the 40th time after a fight it sorta makes you raise an eyebrow, genuinely. That crap is NOT why I'm here and it's sad to me that these adults designing these games find it adds anything to this kinda game.

-I get there is world building and the game GENUINELY at times feels like a re-imagined PS1 game but at times I feel like I'm running down long hallways for no real reason. Are the narrow passages you have to side-step through like...loading screens? Some places are just too big dude. 

-Collect-a-thon. As much as I like that and enjoy it in FF games, this game goes a little too far with the ground clutter. Way too many boxes to destroy. Personally I prefer ~80% of my items to be bought/earned from fights but I'd reckon 70-80% of your important items are in yellow-lit boxes and the battle rewards are mostly for gil. Is what it is. Not necessarily a bad thing, but I would probably enjoy *an hour or 2* Less destroying boxes on the ground.

I have much love for the original version, down to every last detail. There are pros and cons for someone like myself. I love the graphics and how they've been redone. I love the voices given to the characters. I love how interactive the game is, and it doesn't have to cut to a "movie" scene as in previous Final Fantasy games. I don't mind the slight change in the leveling/batting system. It feels more fluid, yet I can access the menu to choose what I want to do for the character I'm controlling. Is it complete control over all the characters with ATB? No. However, for this remake, it feels right. Moving onto changes in the story. There are a lot I agree with, and it was nice to have a change. However, I also felt a lot didn't need a change. That is my opinion, and you must make up your own. It's still a fantastic game, and I love it.

One of the very few examples of being able to iterate on something near-perfection to produce something of an equal or better quality; FF7 Remake does an impeccable job of capturing everything about the original that made it good and transformed it into a new style for a newer generation.

Fans of the original will be pleased with just about everything barring the combat, which you'll either love or hate. The move away from turn-based has been divisive amongst FF fans and while I think it's done well sometimes (like here) and done poorly in others (like FF15, which feels clunky and often time tedious), I do still miss it somewhat.

The PC port is quite polished now and supports HDR, so maxed out it looks like how the original FMVs looked in my kid mind playing OG.

Decent amount of replayability to go through hard mode and find other content, but being the first part of a 3-part epic you could breeze through it and be left wanting more.

With no sign of Rebirth coming to PC yet as of writing this review on 21/09/2024, you may prefer to hold off until all 3 parts are released together.
I'd buy it at full price again. My goat.

Probably the biggest and the longest game among its series and just like yakuza 0, the game is split between 2 mc and offers massive tons of contents and huge variety of mini games that doesnt feel like mini games at all since I feel like clearing the minigame itself consumed more times than the main story. You can find yourself hooked in several minigames for ages like playing sujimon which feels exactly like pokemon, even has their own elite 4 and its dex completing and leveling system is pretty similar. There's also an animal crossing-like minigames where you have to build your own resort island, reach certain milestones to reach 5 stars, catching the fish and insect for encyclopedia, and finding DIY recipes, there's also a minigame that feels like pokemon snap where you must take photos of several sujimons within time limited event, a food delivery minigame where you must perform attracting combos to multiply your score, a 'tinder-like' minigames to hook yourself with girls that will reward you with actual realistic hot pics of featuring girls, and still many returning minigames from sega arcade and collecting cans from like a dragon. Every single corner in this games has its own content that you may even feel overwhelmed to try all of it and I recommend to take it easy, try to not clear each in one swipe as you can easily burnout if you try to do so.

The substories in this games also brings back lots of returning characters for their story continuation or maybe give closure for some of them, that if you've been following yakuza series for long and always keep in check with each games substories, trust me you'll feel grateful. Infinite wealth brings back literally almost the entire major substory characters from yakuza 0, kiwami 1 and 2, 3-5, 6, 7, and even some characters from judgment make a brief cameo in this game, and I feel like this is the biggest fanservice I've ever found in yakuza games, even the music used here is also the same music used from older games and if you notice, kiryu's kamurocho battle theme is the original 'Funk goes on' from its PS2 games!

Now talking about gameplay, it still feels pretty similar like the latest game but with some improvements like now you can manually positioning your party in combat, the enemy now has knockback direction after receiving impact from your attack, whereas if the enemy is flying towards your other party members it will perform something like a chain combo that doesn't cost you a turn, you can now use anything scattered in the battlefield as a weapon to inflict ailments or huge AoE damage, and for kiryu specifically, he can enter the brawl mode for a brief period of time to ignore the turn based system and kick everything on his way, and this is what I enjoy the most when playing as kiryu XD

My only and big disappointment for this game is that they locked NG+  feature and 1 major dungeon behind a $25 DLC, I almost played every yakuza game for 100% achievement but can't do this in Infinite wealth due to that sole reason as the achievement require you to complete the game 3 times and clearing 1 major dungeon that is also included in the dlc, and $25 for just unlocking new game plus is just sucks

[h1]I went through all that life has to offer, just like you. I know how hard that s*** is.[/h1]

When [b]Like A Dragon: Infinite Wealth (LADIW)[/b] first trailer came out, I was really looking forward to coming back to the turn-based JRPG gameplay that the game was going for. I was really excited to what the game improved on with [b]Y7[/b] and what new features that the game had in store for it. With that said, this review will also be a bit hard for me to cover in certain aspects, as I don’t want to spoil anything on the game.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]A very interestingly crafted story with fun characters
[*]Fun turn-based gameplay
[*]Unique jobs that can give you a variety of moves
[*]Lots of side content to do in the game
[*]Fantastic soundtrack that is nice to listen to
[*]Beautiful graphics that make the areas feel alive
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The story loses some of its charm near the end
[*]New Game+ and other difficulties locked behind a DLC
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
[b]Ichiban Kasuga[/b] was working at an average job until he one day gets let go from his and cancled by a [b[Vtuber[/b] on in one day. This is due to a callout video made by a [b]Vtuber[/b] named [b]Hisoka Tatara[/b] and because of this [b]Kasuga[/b], with his two friends, [b]Nanba and Adachi[/b], decide to go to the [b]Seiryu clan[/b], to find answers. Along their way, they meet ex-yakuza members and meet [b]Jo Sawashiro[/b], who then tells [b]Kasuga[/b] to go to [b]Hawill[/b] and find his mother. Although there is a lot more going on then one may seem.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3333939084
The story for [b]LADIW[/b] is pretty good, I really loved the new characters and the returning ones were also nice. I honesty think even telling one of my favorite characters is spoiling the story too much, besides [b]Tomizawa[/b], who is a cab driver and was just a cool character. The story has that classic crime drama that the series is known for.

However, the story does lose some of its charm near the end of the game, as it falls off a tad bit although this is only a minor issue that I noticed. Everything else with the story is great but near the end, it kind of just goes away, although they do leave off with an interesting note for it’s next game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]LADIW’s[/b] gameplay mainly remains the same from the previous entry but there are some changes that I really loved that the game added. Besides [b]Kasuga[/b], everyone will now pick up objects to attack people if they are near them. So if you ever wanted to see [b]Nanba[/b] throw a bike at someone, well now you can. You can also use MP to cast special moves to deal more damage, buff/debuff someone, or heal. Overall, the gameplay is very fun and your characters can learn lots of moves to help them in combat.

During combat, you can also time the enemy's attacks so you can block them to do less damage. One of the newest things to combat for enemies is that they can be in a guard state, when they are in this, they will take reduced damage. To get them out of the guard state mainly, you have to use a grab attack, in which they will be taken out of that state. Your teammates also have a radius on their attacks, they can attack any enemy at any range but if they stay in the radius, they will do extra damage on that attack.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3333941765
Jobs are back as well and there are some unique ones that are with each party member. This time around, all the jobs in this game are very good and there isn’t one that is bad necessarily. However, there are some jobs that are ok for the most part but aren’t bad, it is up to personal preference but I never really came across a bad job in this game for any character. Especially [b]Joongi Han or Seonhee[/b] where their main jobs were just straight up broken.

If you want to switch jobs but keep a certain move, you can do it with a move transfer feature that the game has. Which is very useful to create the ultimate character with the best job with some of the best moves in another job. Although you can only do up to five moves in total completely. So make sure you have the moves that you want to use and keep note of them so you can make the most of them.

There is a ton of side content that the game has in it and some very interesting ones at that. The first one I would like to bring up is [b]Sujimon[/b], which is this game's version of [b]Pokemon[/b], where you battle [b]Sujimon[/b] trainers and challenge gym leaders. Then there is [b]Dondoko Island[/b], where you manage a hotel resort, it’s like [b]Animal Crossing[/b] to an extent. So as you can see, You have three games in one, [b]Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth, Pokemon, and Animal Crossing[/b]. There is a lot to the gameplay that I have not explained but I can’t fit it all into this review, I do talk a little more about this game in my video on it (will be out soon, ran into some problems}. I also rated all the [b]Yakuza[/b] games that I have played so if you are interested in that, keep an eye out for it.

Although despite having all of this great stuff in this game, [b]Infinite Wealth[/b] has one glaring issue with its gameplay or the game as a whole. New Game+, is locked behind a DLC and so is hard mode, in other words, you only have access to one difficulty for the game. The game isn’t that hard either but the fact that a basic game feature is locked behind a DLC just proves [b]Sega’s[/b] greed.

[h1]Graphics, Performance and Soundtrack[/h1]
The graphics for this game are beautiful and I loved how the world that you are in is detailed, each area felt real and it’s like I was in its world. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM, I had no issues while I was playing and I was able to play it just fine, on medium settings.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3333942218
The soundtrack for this game is just fantastic and it even rivals Y0’s soundtrack, my favorite songs in the game are [b]Camouflage, Barracuda, and Giftiger Füllhalter[/b]. These songs just sound so damn nice to listen to and I highly recommend you check them out when given the chance.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
[b]Infinite Wealth[/b] is one of the best games that I have played this year and I am glad I was able to experience it in all its glory. I recommend this game to all [b]Yakuza[/b] fans, especially for those who enjoyed [b]Y7[/b]. You will have a great time with this game and the side content will make sure you are hooked and are playing the game for hours on end.

Filler. Padding. Nonsense.
Three words that fit this game perfectly. There is nothing more infuriating then trying to get on with a game's story just to be thrown into a forced animal crossing bootleg tutorial. The game's story (when it isn't extremely predictable or being hindered by endless filler) is pretty good and I want to see more of it, so it's a shame that you have to trudge through sneaking through crowded streets of enemies for an hour to get to it. It got to the point where I just had to go on WeMod and turn on stealth mode. This game could have been great, but since the seventh entry they've really dropped the ball with the franchise.
Also Ichiban is not a good character. Having a character obnoxiously looking for the good in horrid people doesn't make him a good guy, it makes him stupid, and no matter how hard you try to push this "him and Kiryu are so alike" point it will never make it true.
Really fun gameplay and story so far, highly recommend it!

( full review with screenshots: https://www.gaming-parrot.com/post/infinite-wealth-review-infinite-content )

At a whopping 127 hours by Steam playtime, Infinite Wealth is now the longest game I've ever played by a huge margin. It took me nearly 40 hours longer than its predecessor, and over 30 hours longer than it took to earn a platinum trophy in Persona 5 Royal. Whatever else you want to say about this game, you can't say that you're not getting your money's worth. The bigger question is whether this incredible level of time investment is worth it. Although this is in many ways a great game, it's harder than I'd like to say that it was 127 hours well spent. 

Let's start with the good news. The main story is well done, and you could probably get through it in a relatively normal amount of time for a JRPG if you're focused on it. It has some fun fights and a lot of callbacks that I'm sure are exciting and rewarding content if you've played Yakuza 0-6. The new characters are deeply integrated into the plot and have satisfying arcs. Honolulu is a fun city to explore and feels as different from Ijincho as you'd expect.

A lot of the other things that were good in the last game remain fun. The battle system is still great, and made more so by new jobs. The music is great. There are some entertaining side quests, the minigames are gloriously stupid, and so on. You'd expect at least a few things that are horribly underdeveloped in a game this long, but everything is basically fine at a minimum. 

The bad news is that while nothing truly feels incomplete, many parts of the game would have benefited from more refinement. Although the minigames are fun, there are only a handful of new ones and there's nothing as crazy as kart racing or running a public company from the last game. Most of them, like the parodies of Crazy Taxi and Pokemon Snap are solid experiences that run out of new content after 20 minutes and don't have worthwhile rewards. The highlights are supposed to be Donodoko Island and Sujimon battling, which parody Animal Crossing and Pokemon respectively, but neither of them have the depth to reach their full potential. Dondoko island boils down to spamming buildings all over your island until you get the next cutscene, and Sujimon battling is almost entirely determined by who has the best rarity Sujimon at the highest level. Since each Sujimon only has one move and all moves do pretty much the same thing with different damage totals, there's little reason to anything other than mash A and occasionally swap for type matchups. You need to complete Dondoko Island and the Sujimon league if you want to complete all the quests, but they're each long enough that you could have finished an entirely different game instead. That was one thing in the last game when the minigames were as fun as many other full games, but in this case it really didn't feel worth the time. 

Sadly, the minigames aren't the only place where you get the feeling that the devs didn't get all the time they needed. The story rushes to make sure every major character returns, but several of them clearly have no reason to be back and barely play any role other than being present. The final battles at the end of the game are well made and difficult, but the evil monologues you're treated to reveal that the villains never really had any kind of coherent plan, which makes you wonder what the point of it all was and whether there was supposed to be more content that would have tied everything together better. It's all capped off by one of the main party characters not even being present for the epilogue and instead just getting a single sentence to explain what happened. It's not quite "and then everybody died, the end", but it's hard to imagine an explanation other than not having time to make another epilogue cutscene. 

At the end of the day, Infinite Wealth is a great game that just tries to do too much. RGG wanted to have a sendoff for Kiryu while also telling a new story on the scale of the last game, and they really should have picked one or the other. Although they do a better job of integrating those two very disparate goals than you might expect, trying to cram all of that into a game with anything resembling a normal runtime just means that nothing gets the time it deserved. It's still a good game, but I can't help but wonder if it would have been better as two separate games that each had a single goal. If nothing else, that would have prevented the need to break the cast up into two small parties and given you more flexibility to build your battle team. 

--------

Methodical combat that rewards good decision-making like classic Dark Souls. Although unlike Dark Souls parrying is basically required just like Sekiro except the timing is a bit harder. Although I am a Souls veteran, I struggled immensely on the first somewhat challenging boss because it was pretty much a test of how well you could parry as simply whiff punishing between his attacks did very little damage. So parrying was the only way to get big damage by breaking his posture and riposting him. Once you master that, you've "gotten good" at LoP. There is also the rally system from Bloodborne, which just lets you regain most of the damage taken from blocking if you attack the opponent a few times after. The overall game has the same amount of polish as FromSoftware games, though it has a surprising amount of DNA from Code Vein in the sound and visual effects, and some mechanics like sliding down ladders and interacting with more things at your home base. So far I love it!

Lies of P is a game that was truly fantastic for it's first few hours, drops off a bit by midgame, and becomes an infuriating mess by chapter 7/11.  The first part of this review is for the general game, the second part is the threshold where I accepted it wasn't worth continuing.

Pros:
1.  The Legion arm mechanic is pretty cool.  Essentially preset secondary equipments that can be upgraded to add new passives to them.  Examples include a staggering grapple hook, a charge up electric blast, a landmine summoner, and a a retaliatory shield.  Legion arms allow you to get a boost against harder foes that your weapon proves insufficient for.
2.  Parry mechanics.  Depending on what kind of enemy your fighting, a perfect parry will either help stagger them for a combo hit or help shatter their weapon, reducing attack variety and damage.
3.  Specters act as boss assists if you're frustrated or unable to defeat a boss.  It's a pretty big help if your too frustrated.

Cons:
1.  Underwhelming soundtrack.  The only music in the game outside of the gramophone is against bosses, and they all sound pretty similar.
2.  Finite resources.  There's only one copy of each weapon, armor, and amulet, with no way to get more.  If you sold or missed an item, it's gone forever, the entire playthrough.  Quartz, the skilltree material, can't even cover half the skilltree without running out for the rest of the playthrough.  Cranks, allowing you to tinker with weapon scaling, are also finite, discouraging experimentation.  Consumables have to be slowly grinded for until chapter 5 when you can buy them.
3.  Rushed choices.  Any time the game has you make a narrative choice, it gives you about 6 seconds before automatically selecting whatever your cursor touched last, leaving no time to think anything through.  This leads to decisions feeling incoherent and shallow.
4.  Lack of information.  The game doesn't tell you what three of your six stats even do, making the early game confusing.  Status effects only tell you what they do once they've killed you.

Last part of my review is unfairness.  Up until Elysian Boulevard, the game does quite well with dying being your fault rather than cheap shots or instant death.  Once you reach the boss there, you have your first instance of simply full on stun locking you with no escape method.  Once you trudge your way through that, you soon hit the swamp monster, with the ability to also kill you in one inescapable combo, but with the addition of being far too durable to kill with consumables and shredding your specter.  Outside of bosses, several things lead to being unfair.  Several points have enemy locations that you can't reasonably deal with, leading to barely avoidable damage.

Keep in mind that this is my first souls like, so I can't compare it well to others.  I do enjoy difficult games such as Dead Cells and Celeste, but difficult and unfair are rather different things.

With the DLC on the horizon, I would like to share a few words about this game.... or maybe just one word....."masterpiece".


This game compared to most Souls-like games has given the most care out of any games I have seen. Not many games give an equal fairness into their mechanics besides this one. Every other souls-like game I have played has never given me much satisfaction compared to this one either. The story, the combat, the variety of combat weapons, and the goddamn level design and setting of the game just comes out as one of my Top 10 games of all time. Of course this game is not for everyone but this game has instantly made me wanna play it twice which I never do a lot for most singleplayer games. Highly recommend if you like soulslike with very well done storytelling because this is Lies of Peak!

As someone who's never played a Dark Souls game, this was my first Souls-like experience that I actually finished. I own Elden Ring, but I never completed it because I got too lost in its open-world concept. However, this game was an amazing introduction to the genre, especially considering it comes from a smaller studio, not a massive corporation.

The story is captivating, and the game does a great job guiding you through it. The voice acting is absolutely incredible—most games have at least a bit of cringe in their dialogue, but not this one. The performances are top-notch.

Combat is really fun and rewarding. Parrying can break enemies' weapons, and you can combine different weapons and handles (I mostly used boss weapons throughout the game). I didn’t find the game overly difficult either—you can even beat some bosses with throwable items, and certain bosses allow you to summon an aid, which is super helpful.

The music is also insane. It’s one of the highlights of the game for sure. After beating it, I immediately wanted to start another playthrough, but I’ve heard that DLC and a sequel have been announced, so I’m waiting for that. When the DLC drops, I’m definitely doing another run with a new weapon setup.

If you’ve never played a Souls game, I really believe this is a great entry point into the genre. I highly recommend it!
Combat is not Elden Ring, but it's a solid 8.5/10. Definitely worth a playthrough. I got hooked by the atmosphere and the story.

It's for games like this that Steam needs a scaled rating system. 7.5/10
Great story. Mostly great game. 3 of the bosses try hard to ruin it.

Given the fact that this is a game built almost entirely on parrying, it's frustrating when you can't stop a chain of actions to parry or dodge. Also any hit seems to slightly stagger P. For a split second you can't move and for just slightly longer you can't parry or dodge. Not a problem for most of the game, but for the very fast bosses chaining attacks, it's annoying you can see P not reacting to your input as another attack comes in. Yet for the most part, your attacks don't have the same effect.

There are minor issues with it such as bosses that jump very high in the air, yet the camera angle cannot look straight up. In some places it's like ledges are covered in grease. It's possible to be pinned against a wall or object by an enemy and have no way out, it's effectively a death sentence with certain enemies.

*Minor spoilers*
Most of the bosses are fun with good cut scenes.
3 of them are not fun. The King of Puppets, Laxasia and the Nameless puppet.
There is clearly a reason the achievement % drops off at each of these.
The times I beat them, it was luck of the draw of how aggressive the boss was feeling that round.

Sometimes it feels like that game goes out of it's way to kill you if you do "too well" and get close to killing the boss quickly in the first few rounds. You'll soon be punished with an onslaught. Yet if you just stand there and practice parrying, you don't get the same intense beating.

For the fights with the spectre, for me just using a single HP re-gen wish on it worked well to keep the boss distracted for longer. Other wishes are okay, but nowhere near as impactful as simply having two of you in the battle for longer.

Save throwing items until you have the boss down to <10% health, then use them to help finish it quick. Otherwise don't bother using them, they're effectively a limited resource before you'll have to go out farming for them. 

I beat each of the above 3 by using fable arts and throwables in those last few moments.
Get good and you will find gold.

Think Pinocchio meets Dark Souls after binge-watching Bloodborne. Lies of P is an intense souls-like that nails the creepy vibe with twisted, puppet-filled streets, and a narrative that’s surprisingly gripping.

The combat feels fluid and satisfying, punishing you just enough to make each victory feel earned. The twist? You're a puppet whose lies shape the story and the outcome—so keep your nose (and blade) sharp. It's a fresh spin on familiar mechanics with a gothic charm that'll keep you hooked, even when you're rage-quitting... for the 10th time.

It felt like stepping into another era. Overall, it was an incredible experience—9/10, highly recommend!
