Describing my experience with Lies of P as simply another 'souls-like ARPG' would be entirely reductive to the amount of passion & attention-to-detail presented by the teams at Neowiz and Round8 Studio. Lies of P sees you lead as Gepetto's puppet in a twisted, gloomy take on the folktale of Pinocchio. Waking up in an eerie train station, you soon make your way outside to the city of Krat, where a sudden trigger in the puppets causes a haunting massacre that sets the tone for the rest of the game.

     On that note, atmosphere is the name. Hotel Krat is your central hub, and it quickly evolved from being a brief trip to level up my weapons into a safe retreat where I could listen to a vibrant soundtrack in the background as I spoke with the many charismatic faces that made up this iconic location. It's not just the hub area - everything from oil-lined streets to infested cathedrals, the immense amount of detail present within the level design itself across most of the chapters is incredibly impressive. Whether it was my first playthrough or my sixth, I could not help but immerse myself in all of the intricately placed bodies & texts around the city that truly cements this game as an all-time example of how to do proper environmental storytelling within linear experiences. Neowiz and Round8 really wear the inspiration on their sleeves with the worldbuilding here and it's very well executed. (Note: it runs flawlessly for me on an upper-end rig, but even on my steam deck it is the best performing game I own. It's also very nicely balanced and well-paced. I would say I preferred the difficulty around launch, as it really heightened my enjoyment of this game in a unique way because of how challenging it was. But it's still a decent challenge and NG+ definitely brought that difficulty back.) 

     Combat is really where Lies of P hits all of its strides for me. As a fan of FromSoftware's 'soulsborne' entries for the better part of a decade, I believe Lies of P implements so many positive spins on their formula that I would recommend this over the traditional souls games to any player, regardless of experience (well... maybe play Sekiro.) For example, one of my favorite mechanics is pulse recharge, which allows you to gain one more charge to your healing consumable if you are at zero. This feature would change the entire dynamic of so many of my fights in an instant. Maybe I'm playing defensively, I've got two more heals and 60% of the boss's health left; in scenarios like this, every single time I reached zero heals, my brain would switch to aggression immediately in the hopes of regaining a charge and feel more 'comfortable.' I cannot speak to everyone's experience, but this mechanic made me a better player over time as I was PUSHED into being more active in my gameplay and subsequently rewarded with the most satisfying sound effect I've heard since the Halo CE shield recharge as a single pulse cell materializes right back into your upper belt. 

     Another great feature to the combat sandbox is the ability to assemble weapons. This is the single-most innovative design choice that Lies of P offers. Every weapon comes in two distinct parts, the blade tip and the handle. Each part has their respective stats; however, you can alter the handle to scale off of different stats than the ones it drops with. This opens up a lot of customization and encourages player experimentation, because at no extra-cost, your entire moveset and ability options can change in a matter of seconds. I myself am a Guts sword girl through and through, but even I felt compelled to experiment and eventually beat the game with my own ridiculous combinations. (Note: For me, this self-expression was VERY important in my enjoyment of the game, and I think it's a great innovation to the souls combat formula to allow your players to test out ANY weapon handle's moveset with... every other weapon's blade. Admittedly boss weapons are restricted from being customized and the scaling of both parts' stab/slash stat means that your options for good damage are inherently limited, but it offers so much freedom regardless that I would not mind seeing it return in the sequel.) 

     Story is the point I want to end this off on. For as long as I have cherished Bloodborne's lore, the original trilogy's lore, etc. I have never actually felt connected to the events of the stories presented in souls-like games. There's always been a strange disconnect for me being able to enjoy the challenge of the gameplay rather than caring about the story. I can say Lies of P genuinely moved me in a way no other games in this subgenre have. I believe the most obvious explanation for this is the greater emphasis on dialogue and player onboarding that Lies of P engages in. There is a real sense here with the amount of dialogue you'll receive from a character off-screen during gameplay or in the middle of a boss fight that Neowiz really wanted to make players feel INVOLVED in the big character moments as they are happening, rather than reading about them from a lore description (which is also a method of storytelling present with a lot to read up on that is engaging.) To be clear, I have no issue with this, but I really prefer the focus on character engaging with me, the truths/lies you decide to tell them, and the almost-immediate consequences those decisions can have as they relay their reactions back to you. You can ignore or fight multiple bosses by making a simple decision. I like that. The narrative throughline that is happening above all of the character stories is decently executed, but the character quests is really where Lies of P shines (shoutout to Arlecchino.) Everyone is voice acted phenomenally, and this could not be a Lies of P review without making mention of how pivotal this game's original soundtrack is to the overall experience. The music feels tied to the characters' stories, as many records you can play back at Hotel Krat are received from quest completions. This makes even something as seemingly trivial as playing a record on a record player feel rewarding in itself, as you learn more about an NPC's journey through this world or simply enjoy a great tune in the background. 

     This has become my comfort game, and affectionately so. That doesn't mean it is devoid of things I disliked, as the final area of the game, Arche Abbey, has got to be the single-most tedious level I have played in recent memory. Running through this moody grey wasteland to a grey tower with grey floors and repeated enemies from throughout the entire game got tiring incredibly fast, and it's a shame that the area with this game's pinnacle challenges is also so uninspired in its design. Additionally, I do not think the armor system, dubbed "Defense parts," is particularly exciting. I think this could be fleshed out a little more, but finding more parts throughout the game is almost never exciting because they are always going to be better than your previous find, and they do not change any part of your puppet's appearance. I do like the cosmetics available here, but I definitely prefer the more free-form style of armor expression in other souls-likes. The legion arm system is probably the most disappointing aspect for me, delivering options to customize your limb similar to the prosthetic tools in Sekiro. I do not like the implementation in this game because it feels stiff to me. This is not something I have the knowledge to explain away, but it feels very restricted and with the low amount of legion I always have, it just left a lot to be desired for me because I mainly relied on parrying and counterattacking. 

     Despite my negatives, I adore this game. At the time of writing I have unlocked everything pre-DLC and waiting in anticipation for it as well as the recently announced sequel. If you've ever got a weekend to knockout a surprisingly compelling souls-like, this is absolutely the one for you.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!

Forced to make psn account. Then it made me log in manually instead of auto-logging me in after making it (it's 2024 Sony come on). Already annoyed but it's fine, once and done I thought. NOPE.

It asked me to verify my account from email omg... but yay I saw a "do this later" option which I clicked on. This basically ended the game. Wow. Why are you offering this if it's a lie?

Reloaded game. Opened internet browser and verified stupid email for Sony. Tabbed over to the game and it wouldn't open. After maybe 20 seconds it crashed and Steam gave me a pop up error crash message. So sony PSN account nonsense crashed my game.

Reloaded game. Quite irritated at this point. I had to manually log in again to PSN. It asked me to verify account but I was able to click on "already verified" to get past that. FINALLY I thought... NOPE.

It asked me some annoying questions and terms and data crap but I saw a "do this later" button which I clicked on once again because this shouldn't matter I thought, I should be able to do this later in Settings or something. This ended the game again................................

I reloaded the game and guess what, had to manually log in AGAIN. So damn mad at this point.

I ignored the stupid "do this later" button which should've never existed in the first place because you literally cannot play if you click on it.

Finally got to the damn start screen. I went into settings and maxed everything out as usual. 4090/7950x3d/64gb. Game crashed in settings. I confirmed amd and nvidia drivers were up to date, which they were. Reloaded game.

Finally after like a half hour of bullshit I'm able to play. Thanks Sony! Negative review until the end of time from me.

In the future, any game requiring a PSN account from me will get a negative review even if the game blows my mind.

God of war Ragnarok is a rare type of sequel in the sense that its better than the first game in almost every way. The combat is much more refined to deliver a similar yet more polished experience than the 2018 game. The story itself is a very gripping and enthralling ride that I havent even finished yet despite me having almost 30 hours on the game and im just barely entering the final act. The side missions are very interesting and give some good lore about the areas you explore some of them even relating to characters Kratos and Atreus have encountered before, some of the rewards feel a bit lackluster at times but the game is typically pretty fair with the loot you get. Speaking of side content, there are a plethera of hidden bosses that i've encountered that if succeeding against them can easily get you a lot of xp and hacksilver, the boss fights are challenging yet fun that also feature a lot of different mechanics. Exploring more of the 9 realms is a journey in itself with each realm having a vibrant and unique look and feel, the graphics on this game are very good and sony delivered a very solid PC port so props to them. All in all id give this game a solid 9.5/10 so far, the only critique i could even have for it is that i wish the game was longer however, they were kind enough to make the free Valhalla DLC which is a roguelike experience in the post game that you can get a lot of time out of in itself.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

Cyberpunk isn't a good game by any measure and the less of its setting leaks into the real world, the better but if you do end up playing it, get Phantom Liberty and ignore the main game to the best of your ability.
The dlc is its own thing pretty much with an extra ending of its own, which has the added benefit of skipping the remainder of the core vidya.

Now, onto the good things: the script, the pacing, the dialogues, the execution of a properly polished thriller. The DLC adds some extra missions for old fixers. Fetch quests aside, the quest are good too, adding depth and nuance to the NPCs. Though the most important is the selection of end-game choices you're presented with. Between wetwork, dubious loyalties and complex motivations of dramatis personaes, someone did their homework on intelligence services so a lot of it offers a very authentic experience. A lot of times you leave feeling dirty - because that is the nature of the work. My only criticism is you couldn't off Meyers (it'd be tons of fun, I think), but otherwise it's next to excellent. Johnny's dialogue at the end of the lunar escape was a rare gem, diverging from his usual abrasive rants. Meeting Mr Hands in person was somewhat of a letdown, but more gigs from the sphinxian villain was welcome.

It's difficult to believe the DLC was produced by the same studio as the cliché and filth-filled dumpster fire that is the core game. The setting remains as disgusting as ever, with humanity locked in a dull and primitive state of neo-feudal corporate overlords or communes of plain-roaming barbarians, but Phantom Liberty redeems the price tag. If you find a way to skip to the DLC and just play the extra, do it: it is a real treat for any lovers of a spy drama - something Deux Ex tried and failed to do.

Edit: ending credits animation film was an outstanding tribute to the classic James Bond movies. Stellar.

Ah, “Phantom Liberty,” where the neon lights are brighter, the stakes are higher, and the glitches are… well, let’s just say they’re part of the charm. Imagine if James Bond, Keanu Reeves, and Idris Elba decided to throw a party in Night City, and you get to clean up the mess. That’s Phantom Liberty for you.

The expansion kicks off with the President of the New United States crash-landing in Dogtown. Yes, you read that right. Apparently, Air Force One now comes with a “crash here for plot development” button. You’re hired to rescue her, but not before you navigate through a maze of cybernetic baddies, morally ambiguous choices, and enough plot twists to make a pretzel jealous.

Idris Elba’s character, Solomon Reed, is the secret agent we all wish we could be. He’s suave, he’s mysterious, and he probably has a better skincare routine than you. Meanwhile, Keanu Reeves returns as Johnny Silverhand, still rocking that “I hate the system” vibe but with a touch more existential dread. It’s like watching your cool uncle go through a mid-life crisis, but with more explosions.

Dogtown itself is a marvel. It’s like someone took all the worst parts of a dystopian future and decided to make it a tourist attraction. The local wildlife includes cyber-enhanced gangsters and vending machines that might just try to sell you a grenade. But hey, at least the street food is to die for—literally.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment you’re making life-or-death decisions, the next you’re wondering why your character’s pants have suddenly disappeared. It’s all part of the Cyberpunk experience, folks. Embrace the chaos.

In conclusion, Phantom Liberty is the perfect blend of high-stakes drama, cybernetic mayhem, and unintentional comedy. It’s like a soap opera set in a dystopian future, and honestly, we wouldn’t have it any other way. So, grab your cyberdeck, put on your best trench coat, and dive into the madness. Just watch out for those vending machines.

If you’ve ever wondered what it would be like to survive in a world overrun by zombies, Project Zomboid is the game for you. With a heavy focus on realism and player choice, this survival sandbox offers a deeply immersive experience that few other games can match. Whether you’re managing your character’s health, building your dream base, or evading hordes of undead, Project Zomboid keeps you on your toes at every moment. Having spent over 730 hours in the game, I can confidently say that it delivers one of the best survival experiences available today.

1. Realism Done Right
Despite the fictional backdrop of a zombie apocalypse, Project Zomboid nails realism in almost every aspect of gameplay. The most valuable tip for any new player is simply: "What would you do in this situation?" The game's health system is intricate, with injuries, illnesses, and mental states all playing a role. Clothes protect you from zombie bites, degrade over time, and help regulate body temperature, which is vital. Mechanics like repairing vehicles, dealing with character traits and professions, and managing inventory weight make everything feel real. I especially love how character emotions and moods affect gameplay – it’s small touches like these that elevate Project Zomboid to another level of immersion.

2. An Open World That Never Ends
The current game world is massive, and despite having played over 730 hours, I still didn't explore all the areas. I admire the sheer size of the map, and with upcoming updates promising to expand it further and even include randomly generated maps in the distant future. Project Zomboid also offers infinite gameplay and replayability. It’s one of those survival games you can play over and over without ever getting tired.

3. Sandbox Customization Options
One of my favorite aspects is the ability to tailor the world to your liking. From the number and behavior of zombies to loot distribution, characters (players), and more, Project Zomboid lets you tweak almost anything. It gives you the power to create a world that fits your personal playstyle or challenge yourself with tougher scenarios.

4. Character Creation and Professions
This is hands-down one of my favorite features in the game. Choosing different professions and character traits, both positive and negative, significantly changes how the game plays. I also appreciate the subtle bonuses and drawbacks that aren’t immediately obvious – it adds an extra layer of depth. The balance in this system is present, too, so don’t expect to create an overpowered character unless you tweak the sandbox settings to do so!

5. Community Mods
While Project Zomboid doesn’t need mods to be great, the fact that they’re available is a huge bonus. The modding community has added incredible content, from enhanced realism to new vehicles, traits, weapons, and crafting options. There’s too much to describe in one review! That said, I recommend playing without mods at first to truly grasp the game’s mechanics, but later on, mods can make the experience even better.

6. Skill Levels and Physical Attributes
Project Zomboid features an extensive skill system that allows players to improve their characters through practice and experience. Skills are divided into categories like combat, crafting, survival, and agility, each having a noticeable impact on gameplay. Combat skills such as aiming and reloading become crucial for firearm users, while melee skills like blunt and blade proficiency determine how effective you are with weapons like baseball bats or axes. Crafting skills, including carpentry, metalworking, and tailoring, let you fortify your base, repair clothes, or even create tools from scratch.
Survival skills like foraging and fishing allow you to live off the land when resources run dry, and farming lets you grow your own food, providing a sustainable source of nutrition. Agility skills, such as sneaking and lightfooted, are essential for staying hidden from zombies, while sprinting helps you escape when the situation gets dire.
Physical attributes like strength and fitness are equally important, as they directly affect how much weight you can carry, how fast you tire, and how effective you are in combat. Improving your strength means you can carry heavier loads and hit harder with melee attacks, while better fitness ensures you can run longer distances and recover faster from exhaustion. Each skill progresses the more you use it, making every action in the game feel meaningful and rewarding.

7. Intriguing (But Optional) Lore
While the storyline isn’t central to the player’s experience yet, it does exist, and it’s fascinating. I only started diving into the game’s lore after playing for about 500 hours, and once I did, I was hooked. I went so far as to read up on the game’s backstory online (beware of spoilers!) Exploring the lore adds a new dimension to the game. I highly recommend getting to know the lore yourself!

8. A Sandbox Experience
Want to build? Build. Want to destroy? Go ahead. In Project Zomboid, your creativity (and characters human possibilities) are your only limits. The only challenge is gathering materials, which makes sense given the post-apocalyptic setting. But with enough time and motivation, you can accomplish incredible things. This open-ended approach is perfect for players who enjoy creating and building their own worlds.

9. Active Developer Support
The game is still in early access, and while it may not be updated on a daily basis, the developers deliver large, meaningful updates. They listen to player feedback, fix bugs, and continue to improve the game without ignoring the community, which is something I greatly respect.

10. Hidden Depths
Just when you think you’ve learned everything there is to know about Project Zomboid, it surprises you. The game is full of hidden mechanics and features that add to the depth of the experience. I’ve had several moments where I thought I had mastered the game, only to discover a new layer of complexity. It’s a game that keeps on giving.

11. Fair Price
Finally, let’s talk about the price. For what Project Zomboid offers, the price is perfect. But if you’re looking to save a bit of money, it’s always worth waiting for a sale. Either way, you’re getting your money’s worth for this gem of a game.

Project Zomboid is a truly exceptional survival game that combines deep realism with sandbox freedom. Whether you're fighting off zombies, building your own fortress, or scavenging for supplies, every moment feels impactful. With continuous updates, an active modding community, and endless replayability, it’s a game that will keep you coming back for more. I can’t recommend it highly enough to fans of survival games or anyone looking for a challenging, immersive experience.

GTA V is an absolutely fantastic game—rock-solid gameplay, an expansive open world, and an engaging story make it a must-play for any gamer. The freedom to explore Los Santos and the countless activities available keep the experience fresh and exciting, even after hours of play.

However, I want to share a word of caution for those venturing into the world of FIVEM private party servers, especially for roleplay (RP). While the idea of RP can be incredibly fun and immersive, be aware that many servers are controlled by groups with partisan attitudes and individuals who exhibit narcissistic tendencies. These groups often create a toxic environment where players are subjected to constant bans, kicks, and a myriad of rules and regulations that are enforced arbitrarily, without any empathy or respect.

The power dynamics on these servers can severely affect your mental health. The high egos of those in control can make the experience more frustrating than enjoyable, as they enforce their rules based on personal feelings rather than fair play. It's a real shame that such behavior can taint what could otherwise be a great RP experience.

In summary, GTA V itself is an incredible game that I highly recommend. Just be cautious if you decide to explore the RP scene on FIVEM servers—it's not always the welcoming community you might hope for.

Grand Theft Auto V is the definitive guide on how to live your best life through crime, chaos, and questionable decisions. Set in the sun-drenched paradise of Los Santos, this game is basically an immersive therapy session for anyone who’s ever thought, “You know what would really help me unwind? A heist, a few car chases, and possibly some light arson.”

From the moment you step into the shoes of Franklin, Michael, and Trevor, you realize that you’re not just playing a game; you’re participating in an elaborate social experiment on the human psyche. The core message? Why follow the rules when you can cause mayhem in the most entertaining ways possible? Forget about being a law-abiding citizen—this is America, baby!

Let’s talk about the open world, which is so meticulously crafted that it practically begs you to unleash your inner anarchist. You’ll find a sprawling city filled with pedestrians just waiting to become your unwitting co-stars in your crime drama. Whether it’s jaywalking, causing a minor fender bender, or straight-up committing vehicular manslaughter, the citizens of Los Santos are practically begging for the experience. It’s like the game is saying, “Hey, why not give that guy a good shove? He deserves it!”

The missions are designed to make you feel like a criminal mastermind while secretly reminding you that you’re actually just a glorified taxi driver with a penchant for armed robbery. You can spend hours planning the perfect heist, only to end up accidentally shooting a pedestrian because you mistook the ‘aim’ button for the ‘get in the car’ button. Who knew that “stealth” meant “loud explosions and yelling”?

And then there’s Trevor, the character who epitomizes the phrase “unhinged lunatic.” He’s the friend you invite to parties who ends up burning your house down. Playing as him is like engaging in a game of “How many crimes can I commit before the game decides I’ve gone too far?” Spoiler alert: it’s always “more.” He’s the embodiment of everything society warns you against, yet somehow he’s also the most relatable character you’ll encounter.

Let’s not forget the online multiplayer component, where you can team up with friends to cause even more chaos. Nothing says “bonding time” like robbing a bank together while simultaneously launching a missile at a helicopter because why not? You’ll find yourself questioning the depths of your moral decay as you laugh maniacally at the chaos you’ve unleashed on the virtual world.

And the real estate? Oh, the real estate! You can buy everything from luxury apartments to a beach house, turning you into a digital real estate mogul. Just think: you can own a mansion while simultaneously committing grand theft auto. It’s the American Dream, distilled into a chaotic video game where the most common job title is “criminal.” Who needs a 401(k) when you can invest in stolen cars and questionable business ventures?

In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto V is the ultimate escapist fantasy for those who have ever wanted to live life on the edge without any real-world consequences. It’s a wild ride filled with laughter, mayhem, and a whole lot of questionable life choices that somehow feel liberating.

So, if you’re ready to embrace your inner criminal and wreak havoc in the most entertaining way possible, GTA V is the game for you. 10/10 would absolutely steal a tank and go on a rampage through the city again.

I tried to give this one a fair shake. It has some good qualities, to be sure: The story and characters are fundamentally sound, the character creation system is great, the combat and spellcasting have a lot of cool aspects. 

But it just had too many flaws for me to keep playing. It started with the stealth missions, which were ridiculous and didn't feel at all like actual stealth. It continued with weak quest design that mostly amounted to "go to this place" over and over again. And then it really got worse with random encounter enemies with stupidly huge amounts of hit points that aren't even that hard, they just take [i]forever[/i] to take down.  Finally I realized that I was just getting bored. When the combats aren't fun in an action RPG, the game isn't fun. 

It still has its moments, but overall it just needed a lot more work to be genuinely fun.

I do have to be honest that much of the game NPC interactions are a bit too forward by means of moving the plot with very little nuance. when it comes to the main quest characters there is so much "here have this bucket of respect and this one, oh and look behind you we brought you a truck load of respect have it all. no you just proved your worth when you laid back like a hero while we attacked that troll but we couldn't have done it without you blowing up a dam and sweeping us a great distance down a river whilst destroying a naturally occurring boon to our infrastructure but yeah, we owe you a great deal of gratitude. but for all the goofy stuff this game does as an oversight so early in the game I do love the the gritty visuals, the towns aren't vibrant, they are brown, simply brown. this is supposed to be a medieval fantasy and it delivers. no one speaks with modern slang or a watered down version of it. for the first 20 hours I'm still running from minotaur hoping my companions dont die. I was addicted to start. But after the first like 10-ish hours I just wanted it to end. You fight the same enemies over, and over, and over, and over, and over, and over again. Caves/dungeons are all the same. Boring, repetitive gameplay. Every quest is a fetch quest or escort quest. They make you walk forever from point A to point B which on its own is maybe a 10 minute walk in real time, BUT they also have to throw an enemy encounter in every 5 feet so it takes about an hour to do literally anything. (BTW there's only a few fixed fast travel points, that requires a consumable resource to use, so you're basically walking all the time.)

So it's walk 5 feet, fight goblins. Walk 10 feet, fight harpies. Walk 10 feet, fight bandits. Walk 5 feet, goblins again. And it goes like this forever. Combat is also incredibly basic and easy so it's not even a challenge, just time consuming. Then you get to your destination. Hand over the quest item. "Thanks! Come back tomorrow for the next step!" ........ SOOOO you have to then walk to an inn or campsite (wasting your time, plus every 5 feet fighting something), sleep for a day, then walk all the way back (fighting wolves and goblins every 10 feet). "Thanks! Now meet me in another town for the next step!" 

F**k the f**k off. I think I'm at the final mission, if you can even call it that, and I'm just done. It's so boring, so repetitive, idk if I can even return to it. I'm going to give it a break and come back later to maybe finish this thing off, but idk if I have it in me. 

Oh and the story is stupid as hell. It makes no sense. Stuff just happens with no explanation. There's really nothing even that interesting. The characters are boring and lifeless. 

I'm done writing about this game. There's more to say but I'm just done. If you value your time, spend it elsewhere.

[h1] Dragon's Dogma 2: A flawed masterpiece. [/h1]

[b] DISCLAIMER: Skip to the conclusion for a TL;DR! [/b]

[h3] The Introduction [/h3]
Dragon’s Dogma 2 stands as one of the most beautifully crafted RPGs in recent memory, evoking an unparalleled sense of adventure that few games in the genre manage to capture. Its breathtaking environments begs exploration, offering hidden secrets and unlockables that reward curiosity, while the dynamic and unique combat and pawn system keeps every encounter thrilling. Undoubtedly, there’s a wealth of content to immerse yourself in throughout this experience.

Yet, despite these accomplishments, Dragon's Dogma 2 has sparked considerable debate among its player base. The game’s troubled launch and a series of unresolved issues have left fans divided, with some celebrating its artistic triumphs, while others criticize its persistent flaws. This contrast of opinions has created one of the most polarized gaming communities in my recent memory. So, what is it that makes this game so controversial? Let’s dive into both the highs and lows of Dragon's Dogma 2 and explore what makes it so divisive.

[h3] The Gameplay [/h3]
The gameplay follows a familiar RPG formula, with players exploring the world, progressing through the main campaign (which we’ll dive into later), and tackling a variety of side quests and tasks. However, Dragon's Dogma 2 distinguishes itself with several intriguing mechanics that push the boundaries of what’s typically possible in the genre. For example, players can interact with NPCs to forge replicas of quest items and crafting materials, or unlock areas of the map through secret entrances rather than progressing through the main storyline. These unique features add an extra layer of depth that enhances the overall experience.

That said, the progression system for acquiring gear feels disappointingly linear. Most equipment is purchased from vendors, with options that grow in quality and price as you advance in the game. While the developers attempt to break this mold with secret passages, rare monster drops, caves, and an enhancement system designed to incentivize exploration, the variety is still lacking. More often than not, the gear obtained through these methods isn’t particularly unique but rather serves as an alternate way of acquiring what can also be bought.

This brings us to another area where the game struggles—monster diversity. After about 15-20 hours of exploration, you’ll have encountered nearly every type of creature in the game, which is limited to around 10-12 species. While the game introduces variants of these creatures (e.g., goblins and hobgoblins), the lack of overall variety leaves the world feeling somewhat repetitive. In my opinion, these variations don’t do enough to make the encounters feel fresh or distinctive.

Despite these shortcomings, Dragon's Dogma 2 truly shines in its combat. Every strike feels weighty, and the way enemies respond to your attacks creates an immersive and satisfying experience with each battle. Combined with the iconic pawn and party system, which adds another layer of depth to your encounters, the combat remains one of the game's standout features, especially during your first playthrough.

[h3] The Story [/h3]
Without giving away spoilers, Dragon’s Dogma 2 begins with one of the most captivating introductions in recent RPGs, largely due to the intriguing and mysterious world it presents. Right from the start, the game pulls you in, sparking a desire to uncover the answers to the many questions it raises. As you progress, the story builds toward a grand and thought-provoking finale that can get surprisingly philosophical, which far exceeds the expectations set by the opening moments. I’m especially fond of the ‘true’ ending, which adds an extra layer of significance to the narrative.

However, despite the strong beginning and ending, the story falters during its middle portion. As the plot delves into the politics of the world, it becomes weighed down by confusing narrative decisions and questionable character choices. This muddled direction disrupts the pacing and weakens the overall experience, making the mid-game feel less engaging and cohesive than its opening or finale.

[h3] The Controversy [/h3]
As someone who's never played the first entry of this series, and got into Dragon's Dogma 2 several months post-launch, a lot of the political problems the community has with this game either isn't applicable to me or I had avoided entirely due to some of the problems already being addressed (eg. launch performance issues). That said, the microtransactions that are available to purchase for this game, while mostly unneccessary and doesn't significantly affect you at all, shows the extreme greediness from the developers and publishers. The act of charging real-life currencies for in-game obtainable items in a singleplayer title, especially for something as trivial as what is being offered here, is disgusting and I am only thankful that they did not design certain game mechanics around these paid offerings.

[h3] The Conclusion (TL;DR) [/h3]
Dragon's Dogma 2 is, without a doubt, a flawed masterpiece. Its world is vast and full of wonder, with environments that encourage exploration and mysteries that beg to be uncovered. The combat system, bolstered by the unique pawn mechanic, stands as one of the most engaging aspects of the game, delivering a weighty, satisfying experience that sets it apart from other RPGs. The captivating introduction and philosophical finale also add significant narrative depth that will leave many players reflecting long after the credits roll.

However, the game is not without its shortcomings. The linear gear progression and lack of monster variety detract from the otherwise immersive experience, while the middle portion of the story stumbles under the weight of confusing character choices and narrative intricacies that don’t always land. Additionally, the presence of microtransactions in a single-player game feels like an unnecessary and greedy move from the developers, although it thankfully doesn’t severely impact gameplay.

Dragon’s Dogma 2 shines where it truly matters—its sense of adventure, engaging combat, and unforgettable moments. It’s a game that had the potential to become an industry icon, much like Skyrim, if only the developers had pushed that extra mile to fully realize its potential and delved deeper into the elements that make this game so good. Despite its imperfections, for those willing to look beyond them, the journey it offers comes tragically yet impressively close to earning the title of a masterpiece. I highly recommend giving it a chance.

Just to be clear, I don't recommend this game AS-IS and I certainly would not play it without a mod for the save file system (see my review for more on this). I do not think it is worth the price of $70 which was what I paid for on release. I think maybe if it ever gets to $15 I would say go for it and even then, get some mods. I also really enjoyed the first game and it's the only reason I decided to buy this game day 1 instead of waiting for reviews or friend recs like I normally would. I wish I had!

And yes, I was in the first wave of players taking high doses of cope, saying 'yeah it's fine that you have to buy ferrystones, I practically find them everywhere! oh it's FINE that there's few portcrystals, you can just find more! oh the cash shops not a big deal, you can just FIND all the cash shop items' *cue clown makeup*

It's not fine. Once I had put in maybe 20 hours into the game I realized I absolutely needed mods to make it palatable.

Things to consider as positives:
-Cool to see some new classes
-NPCs will randomly find you or start a conversation with you themselves out of nowhere and these sudden encounters will often start quests. This does make the world feel more real and alive and probably my favorite quest-related feature
-Combat feels very similar to monster hunter, if you like those games you will probably enjoy the combat in this one
-Some quests are 'timed' in that if you spend time doing stuff and don't complete the quest on time it can fail (imagine the quest is to escort someone safely - if you just run off they will probably die). For some quests, this adds realism and could be seen as a positive

Things that made me download mods immediately and feel sad I paid full price (or really any price):
>The save system is unacceptable for a game of this day and age, let me explain:
Without mods, you can never see the list of save files with information that tells you what you were doing. How many times have you put a game down and come back and before loading went 'Hmm I forget where I was in the game?'. In DD2 there's no timestamp, no screenshot, no list of saves to consider to help you piece together which save makes sense to choose.

Now you might say 'Well just load the save and find out!' and sure, that's not a bad idea. EXCEPT! There are ONLY 2 save files to load: one that is based on manual loading and one that is automatically made whenever you sleep at an inn. IF YOU LOAD THE INN SAVE IT WILL DELETE THE MANUAL SAVE. Does the game warn you? Sure. Have I ever spammed the continue button because I'm just trying to play my game only to realize whoopsie - checking my inn save has made me realize I should load my manual save but I can't CAUSE IT'S GONE? Yeah. This is not fun gameplay. It's not fun to worry I'm about to hit the wrong button and ruin my playthrough and lose hours of progress. This is not a fair mechanic. In this era of gaming it's just not acceptable to be given zero information on the state of a save file so that I either had to have made hand written notes or load the file to see where it is WHILE ALSO PUTTING IN PLACE A PUNISHMENT FOR LOADING AND CHECKING. If the devs want to claim that they just don't want people save scumming then give us a way to know what state the saves are in relative to each other! 

On top of all that, the 'manual' save I mentioned is not really a manual save. If the game autosaves (and I cannot find a way to turn autosaving off natively) it will OVERWRITE YOUR manual save. There is not multiple saves like in other games where your manual saves and autosaves are in a list. It's. Just. One. Save. Again, in this day and age this is simply unacceptable. 

>Travelling in the open world without mods or buying teleport items is torture and this sadly feels like incentive to spend real money buying teleportation items:
At time of writing there has been an update to finally add a fast travel point to the other major city you will want to spend time in. On launch, there was only one freely given fast travel point. If you aren't familiar this game uses a system of fast travel where you have to use a consumable to teleport, and can only teleport on Portcrystals - a very rare item you can find so that you can place them and create your own fast travel points. Now this game also came on launch with a cash shop that had many people upset and that I at first, did not fully appreciate, because the shop offered buying of these teleportation items but you could also find them in game. So I thought, what's the harm? Well dear reader the harm is like I said - there was only 1 freely given permanently placed Portcrystal (fast travel point) in the first major city. After that, good luck finding more.

This meant that if I wanted to travel ANYWHERE I had two options:
-walk / run (but mind you have stamina when running that has to recharge)
-take the Ox Cart system
The walking at first was fun. I was totally like 'heck yeah, I'm gonna kill everything that shows up and become so levelled and strong and also explore - THIS IS AWESOME'. 10 hours in I was like 'dear god... please stop spawning... I'm so low on health and I can't get to a campfire... do I even have a camping kit (which you need to sleep and get health back at a campfire). Basically, it feels like the devs have a monster spawn timer of every few minutes so that it feels like you're constantly fighting when you're just trying to travel from one place to the next. The ox carts system are the devs way of trying to help - you basically pay a fee and ride an in-game public transit. You can hit a button to 'sleep' and immediately wakeup at your destination but the catch is that SOMEtimes a monster will attack the ox cart and this will 'wake' you up and for me it was often a gryphon or other large monster that just obliterated the ox cart. In summary: not using the fast-travel system sucked, which DOES feel like a blatant move to get me to buy fast travel items with real money. Thankfully there are mods that will just let you fast travel anywhere for free and I highly recommend using them.

>The new classes require effort to FIND and can be missed without using a guide:
You can argue that playing the game and unnknowlingly discover the quest or NPC that will lend you the new DD2 classes is magical and makes the experience special and that's your right. In my opinion it's a pitfall and pretty lame. I'm not saying I need an NPC in the main city that just let's me try the new classes or that I should be given the new classes by default (though honestly I would be happy with that) - but my goodness, I spent the 60 hrs I have at time of writing not wanting to spoil things and just assuming a main quest or main NPC would nudge me in the right direction. I gave up and looked online and found I already missed one of the new classes and now feel paranoid I will miss the others. Don't hide a cool main feature of your sequel game! 

All in all, I really wanted to love this game. That's why I bought it on launch with nothing but hopes and dreams, that's why I waited until NOW to write a bad review when I already saw so many, telling myself that maybe I should just keep playing and give the game a chance. At this point I wish I could refund it and wait until they give more updates or simply watch a streamer play it instead. I'm not even sure I will finish playing but if I do and the ending somehow makes up for any of it I'll update my review.

Frame rate drops massively outdoors which makes combat extremely difficult even on casual, facial animations are basically non-existent, lip syncing is less actually tied to words and is more like in anime where their mouths move up and down when they speak, voice acting ranges from bad to acceptable at best, pawn commentary is repetitive and annoying, and the story isn't tied together well at all. Haven't even gotten through the first part yet and there have been multiple times I see a character and wonder who in the world this is supposed to be while the plot treats them as though they've been present and important for ages. You have amnesia and I'm guessing don't remember anything at all including anything about the world or the Arisen, but the writing doesn't actually do anything with that so it just feels like random people will show up, somehow know you're Arisen, and then give no opportunity for explanation or for you to be like "okay who are you and why should I care that I'm Arisen, whatever that means" which just makes the interactions feel awkward.

Got this on sale and it's not even worth that. The only reason I'm not refunding it is because I've played past the refund window, so now I'm just hoping some miracle will happen and I'll find a reason to like this game.

Genuinely can't believe it was allowed to be released in this state. The world it's set in has interesting ideas, but that's about all I can say.

This isn't so much a review of the game. It has its issues and its high points, the highs well outweighing the lows of course. My only gripe with the game was that it wasn't long enough. Sometimes a good journey makes you feel just that though.

This is more of a short love-letter expressing my feelings after finally having completed the game. I haven't played the first game, I plan to do that soon enough but this one, from the moment it began, had me hooked. The story isn't the most unique in the world but it's my favorite trope for sure.

The things that made this an unforgettable experience for me [b]SPOILER HEAVY[/b]

[spoiler]Making companions, proving your worth through valiant actions and winning hearts is something a good hero's journey always has. But these actions also breathing life into your pawn who is thought to be this soulless husk who exists solely to be your thoughtless bodyguard, causing them to manifest a humanity within them is perhaps a romantic overexaggeration but that's just the way I consume these stories. Seeing the MC and the pawn create this unspoken yet unbreakable bond and to defy fate together was just so beautiful. Even if it resulted in the ultimate sacrifice for them both in the pursuit of freeing the world of its shackles. It was perfect and an unforgettable experience. [/spoiler]

While playing the game if you aren't someone who believes in the suspension of disbelief, you will see this as a fun, albeit slightly short Action RPG vaguely reminiscent of Monster Hunter. Which even on its own features epic battles and amazing ways to tackle various beasts, fights and tasks. There's tons to explore, many things I didn't even manage to find and will return in NG+ to fully explore. There's a lot of room for experimenting and buildcrafting.

But to me, the game will remain a journey. One that can be labeled as a humanistic fable. I only wish there was more opportunities and quests to spend time with all the NPCs and the main pawn to help make the transition of acquaintances to strong bonds more believable. I loved every moment.

LET ME EXPLAIN. Overall, I love this game. I really do. If I ignore Mario Games, Grounded has become my favorite video game of all time. I got into the game on version 1.3. Played the PC Pass Version with my friend, nearly finished the game. We quit right before 1.4 because we got busy.
Loved the game so much that I decided to buy it on Steam. I wanted to 100% it on Whoa! difficulty. Before I started this playthrough, I did see online about how bad 1.4 was balanced. I even saw how some YouTubers who focused on Grounded quit the game.
Now I see what they were talking about. When I started my 100% playthrough, it was right before 1.4.4. The game still has a bad balancing issue. NG+ is still just broken and unbalanced. to the point where it isn't enjoyable. Two examples: an infused bug can have the sour or fresh spell. They are just insane and barely possible to stop. I was pre-NG+ maxed out on equipment and stats. Even Infused Lawn Mites are a struggle. Also, it is now a grind to get the gear maxed out. The amount of fusion crystals it takes to upgrade a weapon from 9-15 is 105, and the time to get that is just nuts.

If you ignore NG+, the game really is amazing. I really do love this game, but NG+ balancing is just terrible. People can comment that it is a skill issue, but 1.4.4 didn't help much.

Grounded is a game that pulls you into a world where the ordinary becomes extraordinary, and it does so with an incredibly charming and whimsical art style. From the moment you shrink down to the size of an ant and step into the backyard, you’re immersed in a beautifully crafted environment that feels both familiar and fantastical. Every blade of grass towers like a tree, every droplet of water shimmers with detail, and every tiny pebble feels like a boulder—Grounded transforms the mundane into something magical.

The art style is where this game truly shines. The bright, vibrant colors bring the backyard to life, giving it a playful and inviting feel. Despite the dangers that lurk in the grass, there's an undeniable warmth to the world that makes exploration feel rewarding. It captures the essence of being a kid again—where everything feels larger than life, full of wonder and possibility. The way the sunlight filters through leaves, the texture of a dandelion puff, and the glistening of dew drops all add to the sense that you’re in a living, breathing micro-ecosystem.

The attention to detail is remarkable. Each insect is brought to life with such care, from the twitching antennae of ants to the translucent wings of ladybugs. These creatures move and behave in a way that makes the world feel alive, and interacting with them is both thrilling and enchanting. There’s something incredibly charming about watching a line of ants march off with crumbs of food or hearing the distant chirping of crickets as night falls.

Even in moments of danger, when a wolf spider comes charging out of the undergrowth or a bombardier beetle sprays its acid, the art style retains a sense of wonder. It’s a perfect blend of cute and creepy, striking a balance that keeps you invested without losing the game's whimsical tone.

The overall aesthetic of Grounded makes it feel like a love letter to adventure and curiosity, capturing that childhood sense of exploration where every corner of the yard feels like a brand-new world to discover. It’s a game that invites you to slow down, look around, and appreciate the beauty in the little things.

If you're looking for a survival game that offers more than just crafting and combat, Grounded stands out with its charming art style and world design. It’s a delightful experience that turns a simple backyard into a vibrant, awe-inspiring adventure playground. Whether you’re playing solo or with friends, you’ll find yourself constantly amazed at how enchanting the tiniest details can be.
